headline: Like the job, management likes to nitpick.
pros: It’s a really good career and opportunity to work there. I would work at any BB&T branch but not this region/cluster. The pay is great, benefits are amazing, insurance is okay, and clients are great (most of the time)
cons:
However, branch/cluster management in this area is a joke. Following rules is more important than teammate morale and support. They will throw you into a situation you have no idea what to do and ask you why you are not doing it. Or why you didn’t do it well.
They like to single out individuals and don’t treat people equally or properly train their employees.
Personally, I find it ridiculous to not be working the job you were hired to do. Not to mention how singled out you can be if you’re not the perfect person (without illness, etc). Don’t even get me started on the snide little comments played off as joking or “in good fun”. It’s hostile and downright toxic. At least at this location. Idk about the others..

headline: Unbeatable Benefits
pros: 6% matching 401k, up to 40 paid personal days plus paid vacation time based on position and years of service along with good health insurance options and financial guidance/planning.
cons: Not a lot of growth opportunities in smaller markets. They are slower than other financial institutions to offering remote positions.

headline: Good Company, Good Values; Definitely Needs Some Changes
pros: Upper management is wonderful.  District and Regional managers really care about employees.  I was approached for a promotion after only a year within the company.  I have witnessed upper management go to bat to keep employees within the company, or to help them keep employment when moving out of state.  Lots of room for advancement.  Competitive salary.  Awesome benefits and great programs to help assess health and lower the cost of benefits even more.  Generous PTO and vacation purchase programs.
cons: Branch assistance is minimal.  It is not for lack of trying; the company just doesn't have enough staff to support.  Often times, I have been left with one other person to run a branch for a week.  This, of course, creates client frustration, and the employees take the brunt of that.  Hold times on technology support phone lines are often times 5-6 hours.  This lack of support creates high turnover.  It is difficult to get new hires into the appropriate classes, (sometimes over a month-long wait, which means that it takes 2 months from hire to truly have the employee up and running), which further adds to the issue.

headline: Good and Bad
pros: Health benefits, 401k, and pension are your pros. Period.
cons: Only managers make commission based off the branches sales and they don't have to share with employees so you can work your b off and only they benefit. And they will work you without lunch breaks if you're short staffed for the forseeable future, where you're only hope is either your state having laws on breaks or more ppl being hired eventually. Very disappointing company to work for.

headline: Good pay,  Management/Communication Issues
pros:
Good Pay, Good benefits like vacation time, paid holidays, pension plan, 401K etc.

Good banking products and services
cons:
Anyone outside of the branch setting has little respect for branch associates.

Very little consistency - Operations team does not communicate with retail team, so the branches suffer from being told one thing today, the opposite tomorrow from different sections of "bosses" the branch reports to.

Only cares about "big picture" community, not really the small town, local impact.

Regional level management is rude and treats people poorly.

Higher management receives feedback from clients about consistent long wait times in branches and staffing issues, but this feedback is always turned back onto branch staff, rather than the root of the problem. Clients complain they wait in line for 10 minutes, and it is considered the teller lines fault because they didn't thank the client for their wait, didn't give the client the attention they needed once they get w/ an associate, wasn't empathetic enough, etc. 

Career Opportunities depend on your regional area - and often times depends on who you know. Yes, they'll post a job and technically follow the guidelines so i'm sure they're within their legal requirements, but usually someone is already in mind for the job and slides right in. 

I truly think the culture/values is intended well, but when it filters down the ladder, much of that is lost.

headline: No work/life balance
pros: PTO is good if you have worked there a long time. The insurance was good for a single person but expensive for a family.
cons:
No work/life balance.  Always understaffed. They had enough employees for an average day if everyone was in the office but with a large department there is always someone out on vacation/sick and employees were always struggling to get work done. Overtime was expected everyday, sometimes not getting home until 9pm at night some nights. Not a good work environment for employees who have children they have to pick up by a certain time. And if you had to leave you were looked down upon because you weren't contributing.  They expected work to come first and family second. 

Managers micromanaged the supervisors and staff.

headline: Good benefits, but minimal growth opportunities
pros: Salary is above industry average, Pension, 6% 401k Match, Great Health/Dental/Vision insurance with health wellness incentive programs that practically pay for the whole bill. Good work/life balance, I never had to take my work home with me.
cons: Growth opportunities seem to be becoming less likely on the retail banking side. I had been told since I started that I would have endless opportunities to move up, but as they down sized/closed branches, I found myself stuck in the same position. I had also seen where upper management would hold back tellers from trying to be cross trained/move into a banker role just simply because they did not want to have to go through hiring a new employee, which is just wrong. I joined through a merger, and it was poorly executed. The employees sent to train us would argue/bicker about how they do things differently at their branch, and by the time we reopened no one knew what was going on. The transition was so bad that almost 4 years later, clients still complain about how much they wish BB&T didn't take over.

headline: Very corporate, ALWAYS understaffed
pros: The pay was decent, great coworkers, bank holidays and time off was definitely a plus
cons: Very corporate...I could never speak with anyone directly about issues I was having, the schedule was completely random and we wouldn't receive it until very late every week, my branch was always understaffed and it made fora very stressful environment. Since my branch was not open on Saturdays, I was sent to another branch that was an hour away to work for 3 hours. The turnover rate in my region was extremely high and everyone seemed very unhappy and stressed most of the time. It was also extremely sales oriented and if goals were not made...let's just say it was not pretty.

headline: Bank Secrecy Analyst II
pros: Vacation, Sick Days, 401k, work from home-temporarily
cons:
No room for promotion, only friends of supervisors get promoted, does not allow you to go get special training. Training is a watch/drive/crash course in learning; this position is BIG on quota/daily numbers regardless of what you have been taught. 

Even after writing 1 SAR you are still required to clear 4-5 cases per day; when everyone knows a SAR could take half a day. 

In the past some were given promotions “secretly” and when asked, supervisors wanted to know who asked and why? Instead of teaching their employees what/how to do their job in order to get promoted. If you don’t like change and just want an 8-5 job with benefits this is the job for you, but if you are self-motivated this is NOT the job for you!

headline: Decent company
pros: BB&T has an admirable mission and culture statement. There are a lot of in-house promotions and with the level of turnover you can move quickly from teller to management  assuming  you are liked by the right people.  The company provides  a great deal of  training if you choose to pursue it.
cons:
Some of the systems and processes are ancient which result in frequent errors.  The fees are also extremely high. This upsets clients which is a problem when your job is to keep clients happy. 
Every department is divided by what they have access to and your job is interdependent on the competence of others. There is a high rate of turnover. A great deal of pressure is out on managers to perform. This stress is then passed onto employees which can create a depressing environment where they are not empowered nor given the resources, tools or encouragement to succeed.

headline: Harassment (Former Teller “BBI”)
pros: Salary is great, room for advancement if motivated. My direct manager was great, gave me more responsibilities as time went on. I was very appreciative of that. I loved to show my capabilities and loved challenging myself.
cons:
-Harassment from team members to go against compliance. It’s a bully type of environment if you don’t give into peer pressure. Getting pressured to do things the easy way instead of the correct way is not a good feeling, especially when no one speaks to you after doing the right thing. I will never go back to working with people like that.
-Physical branch was disgusting, leaks into carpet, leaks from ceiling, immense amount of dust, oh also a customer actually took a dump in the trash can in our bathroom and one of our team members was told to clean it, location was horrible.
-Favoritism definitely exists amongst team members, not inclusive of whole team. Was a huge wake up call. 
-Vacation is minimal. 
-Systems not user friendly, extremely out dated.

cons: After 3 years of getting the Center up and running, providing weeks of training to each associate and all working a lot of overtime-the closing of our center has been very disappointing. Being part of a reduction in work force is the worst! Too many changes too often-just when you learn something-it changes...again; Officer promotions have no salary increase; the company is so big now, it is hard to know who does what.

headline: Unrivaled training / unrealistic expectations
pros:
Excellent training and “university” 
Technology for branch operations
cons:
Unrealistic expectations and impossibility of family work life balance in the branch environment.  Sales expectations, scheduling and limitation of employee empowerment to make battlefield decisions. Policy overrides common sense in most situations. Lack  of ability to provide exceptional service.   Limited support for managers to coach and grow their teams because managers are expected to be the lead sales champions.  Lack of independent thinking (another core value) and fostering an environment to solve problems on your own.
Unfair and deceptive practices regarding goals and “matrix” - lack of transparency from senior leadership.  Inability to grow or move out of the branch if you are successful (senior management wants to keep you in the position even if you are above qualifications for role)  unstaffed branches and too many branches in market areas.  Pride and ownership are not evident amongst regions.

The management staff is called Market Leaders, meaning that the do not know what the tellers are doing only the bankers. I was the only teller, so when I was on vacation or out sick the management had no idea how to implement my job responsibilities.

headline: BB&T
pros: Fantastic corporate culture.  Excellent benefits.  Getting better all the time
cons: Difficult to move up from within the company

headline: Run away
pros:
Some good people and a decent pension plan.

They used to stand for something. They used to live their mission but they've lost focus on associates and unless you're blind no one true feels like they matter anymore. Pro is with Kelly King still CEO for now his true to life belief in their mission could get fixed. Doubtful but it could happen
cons: Zero work life balance if you want to look good. Push for sales and make the partners work against each other. Hiring new people in at more than what they pay existing employees and existing employees will never get to those income levels at the tiny raises you get annually. Renew those lines of credit for business but they don't count to goals so sell sell sell to hit numbers. Spend all your time on this mandatory or you get yelled at conference call or webex or in person meeting yet run your team, meet with businesses, and hit your numbers. Do the job of fifty people because some scheduling system says you aren't that busy. Mystery shops have to be perfect yet the shoppers outright lie and the company takes their word over provable notes to show otherwise.  Changing goals every month or don't tell you what you have to sell to keep your job until the new year is well under way and then change them again in a few months anyhow and then again after that. Technology is so far behind. Days to process mobile deposits. Still batch scanning teller work instead of live scanning it. Segmentation and lending limit changes up then down then back up again but you've already handed over a bulk of those higher accounts because your limits dropped sorry too late go create new opportunities that other banks selling all the same stuff already are hitting them up for at much lower rates or fees. Oh the fees for everything. Logs oh the logs. Don't forget to log it. Which log the paper logs a plenty. The account service logs for contacts. The check in sheets for logs. Log log log log log log log. Spend more time logging than you do anything else. If systems were more intuitive or not old DOS blue screens half the logs could auto generate and would not be necessary. Log it initial here, sign there, did you email this person to tell them you logged it? Micro manage you out the wazoo. Have the SSL covering so many branches that they can't even meet with and spend time coaching Market Leaders once a month because they have more direct reports than there are business days in the month. So that means the people who talk a good game can just talk talk talk but not do do do as long as they have a good producing location they have to do zero work. No upward mobility. They eliminate positions left and right so no confidence in stability or job security even if you do a good job and are a top producer. Annual vs. Quarterly or monthly incentives like most other banks. Cheap out and tell the branches not to even order lollipops for the kids or dog bones for the pups. Set timers on our lights and heat controls to be corporate managed that they can't trust us to have our own heat set for our own comforts or to turn off a light like we are two year olds. It's a game of how much can people take before they break but we'll talk a good game of culture and expect our employees to live it but what we throw at our employees we as a company don't drink our own mandated koolaid. Pretty sure they named their position Cluster Market Leader because it is a Cluster but different second word. Same salary to run two, three, four, or even FIVE branches with all different goals and just one you. Sure get a team lead that is a glorified platform and that's all the help you need right? You can hit all those goals and coach everyone and be everywhere right? Oh you can't, oh well, figure it out because you're really not branch managers but business relationship managers so that day to day of the branch you can forget time to do it and focus all on business sales sales sales. You still have to get that day to day stuff done but don't dare do it on their business calling time you'll have to figure that out on your own time.

headline: Financial advisor at this Bank
pros: Very Small organization of less then 350 Financial Advisors so you have access to the top of the management chain if needed. Small organization feel with great flexibility.   Pension.  Good name brand with great reputation in Banking.
cons: They promote based on Politics and nothing more.  If you come in to the training program out of college you will be given a free pass.  Antiquated programs that other firms abandoned long ago they keep pumping money in to hoping for a different result.  Bankers who they dub Financial advisors  with no experince who don't have any idea how to give impartial advice because they are driven by product sales goals and push high cost services other firms offer for free.  They don't reward drive and motivation to succeed and prefer you be a robot and stay in your lane.  If you try to stand out and do more that will get you called out for being different.  The most important metrics  for a Financial advisor are over shadowed by the Banks VERY heavy hand pushing to sell products to pay for bad investments it made.  The WORST technology in the business, how can you call yourself an expert in the Stock market when you don't offer Real Time quotes to the Advisors because "it costs too much"???  Lastly and possibly most important NO Diversity its a very Old southern bank...no desire to change that toxic culture unless they can profit from appearing to want change.  Minorities with talent leave the bank for more diverse opportunities as soon as they can because they know they have little opportunity there.

headline: Mixed Feelings
pros: Benefits and Pay are good.
cons: Pay not equal to position (tellers and BB's make very similar pay with a huge difference in responsibility and job functions) and training is highly inadequate for handling customer money.  We run short staffed and every banker is working teller line every other day-while still trying to maintain our sales quotas.

headline: Branch Banker
pros: BB&T has a great mission statement and written values.  Great benefits that start on day 1 of hire date.  Wonderful clients to serve.  Decent salary.
cons: Only receive 2 weeks of vacation for the first 5 years of service.  Way too many Saturdays are expected to be worked by a limited staff.  Each employee works about 3-4 Saturdays per quarter and sometimes there are two in a row.  Management doesn't share in the Saturday rotation so all of the workload is placed on the Branch Bankers.  Horrible work/life balance.  Upper management expects each BB to relieve their Saturday hours/overtime (4 hours) spread throughout the week and you're not allowed to relieve all 4 hours in one day.  BB I and IIs are tellers, however BB III and IVs are expected to manage a desk and full teller responsibilities.  It's difficult to be logged in to 2 computers everyday and the demanding expectations create a fast burn out rate.  Lots of turnover.

headline: Pretty terrible

cons: My manager was very young and did not have managerial experience. He was promoted because he was good at sales. Reason being that’s all the company cares about. Bankers are supposed to make 50 cold calls a week. Credit cards and loans are pushed heavily under the disguise of solutions. Upper management is on retail managers back constantly and our area manager persistently berated my manager. Nothing was good enough. It is a high pressure sales environment even though we should have been focused on just helping customers. Every customer was supposed to be viewed as a potential sale. The environment/culture was terrible. Most of coworkers supported trump and they were vocal about it. Cursing at tv when Hilary gave concession speech calling her curse words. Employees getting fired to save money raise stock price and employees left have to work twice as hard. Older coworker was pushed out because she was out too many days for flu and for her age.

headline: Company Review
pros:
Benefits
Company Pension 
Banking Hours
cons:
Company is more concerned about bottom line than employee needs. 

Employees have low moral 

The company is shifting towards a universal banker strategy, which is great in theory but what upper management fails to realize is that when you have a limited staff doing a bunch of stuff running at 200% employees become counter productive.

I think the upper management staffing model consists of considering how many employees you actually  need to run a location and then dividing that number by 2 . Branches are always understaffed and employees are under-trained.

The technology is the branch is 10 years behind at a minimum 

Its very hard to move up.

headline: Great People - not so great Executive Management
pros: Pension plan, opportunities to advance, colloborative atmosphere
cons: Executive Management and board tha allows Executive Mgmt to earn millions each year in base compensation and stock while providing rank and file employees 1-2.5% max merit increase year over year.

headline: Stay Away
pros: Competetive Salary the rest of the benefits are below standard
cons: Fossil of a company. BB&T treats employees like children.  They are only interested in people who can help them achieve compliance while not thinking critically about the major limitations of the technology environment. If you are interested in being treated as a professional take a pass. They have done so many minor league things since I have left including cancelling the debit card to my flex spending account, downgrading my checking to some antiquated product that includes an annual fee (i didn't even know these still existed). They also have a time off accrual calendar where you don't accrue your last day until the last day of the year and it is use or lose. This results in always having a negative balance which doesn't seem like a big deal until they cut your final paycheck in half. The place is petty and it permeates the culture the successful managers are people who have learned to escape accountability and  stay quiet about the complete lack of a technology strategy.

headline: DON’T WORK HERE
pros:
34k a year with 5 paid vacation days and 10 paid sick days. 

Good health insurance after day 1.
cons:
Disorganized, outdated, sketchy, no work-life balance, dishonest, stressful, annoying, etc. 

I walked into a terrible mess of a branch and a company. There were four of us at the start and my first week was great. 

After my second week a coworker retired, my branch banker team leader was “no longer with the company”, my cluster branch manager “stepped down”.  

I was off in training at another branch for teller mentor training and came back to a hell hole. A branch with no leader and three new people. ( no manager, no team leader, supervisor ) it was horribly confusing and uncomfortable. 

ALL THE CLIENTS were very rude because we new people are required to ask for IDs obviously. I was out of balance and so were the other newbies.... ( we all had only three days of teller training ) No one was around to help and it was the worst experience. We had one violent “client” that we had to call the police on. THE POLICE NEVER SHOWED UP. 

I was also promised I would not have to work every weekend which turned out to be untrue. I was on the schedule 6 days a week every week. That really mad me angry. 

Besides all of that mess at my permanent branch : 

When I was in training at another branch, I saw how everyone hated their jobs and wanted to leave the company. In fact, one did leave that branch the week I was there. 

I was treated terrible by clients because of all the unfair fees BB&T charges. Clients were mean in general. 

I was shorted training days for teller mentor training so I had to put my foot down to get back into training bc I was not ready. They tried shortening up my banker mentor training so I could keep working every Saturday. I had to put my foot down again and say no “I DESERVE FULL TRAINING”!  It’s so important to train employees right especially in this field. I have worked for two other banks that have done such a better job at preparing you. I was set up for failure. Don’t work here.

headline: Branch banker
pros: Good pay, good benefits, vacation time and sick time right away
cons: Long hours, can be very stressful

headline: Teller
pros: Pay is only reason to work at this place.
cons: You pretty much have to train yourself . you are just thrown out there to learn ready or not. Nobody ever seems to be helpful in answering your questions to help you ... Internal employees aren't much help half of them don't know what they are doing when they tell you how to do something. Policy changes often to suit them so don't get used to anything.. Other  Co -workers try to be your boss when they know nothing. Too many clicks and behind the door talking regarding other employees confidential issues. Management violating employee privacy and other employees know your problems before they are addressed to you. Always vacation issues with co workers. When calling internal they give you the run around and still no answer.  Phones ring off the hook all day no call center available. Pressured from management to make calls for them while they do nothing.  Schedules are worked to their management advantage and to your worst. Have to push and pray to get through your days. Just bunch of BS.

headline: Branch Banker
pros: Basic hours, pension vested after 5 years
cons: Salary can be better, time off

headline: Micro micro managing
pros: I have met some nice co-workers
cons: The worst company I have ever worked for, bar none. Vacation is inadequate, sick days allotted but don't use them because they count against you. Micro managed to the max ! Not enough help so people are on hold for long periods of time just to talk to a rep. Never enough help to answer questions. Ridiculous "wrap up" time. Work life balance is a joke with this company, it's all about work.  If you are stuck on a call and can not take your break or lunch at the allotted time, that counts against you as well. So clicky it's nauseating .  Every call is recorded and then you are graded on three calls a month and can get "written up" if you didn't perform to their specifications. This company needs a ton of help for sure ! They pull better employees off the phones to answer questions for co-workers when we need them manning the phones to assist in taking care of clients. Seriously, think long and hard before accepting a job here.

headline: Average schedule with average pay

headline: Community Bank - Corporate Department
pros: Great benefits, value-driven culture, generous, caring, engaged colleagues.
cons: Not enough FTEs, which leads to exec management expectations unrealistic to successful and thorough execution (at least not without returning to the problematic atmosphere of skillfully unspoken but subtly pressured overtime for exempt employees).  The watercooler talk is heightening regarding long-term, dedicated associates considering outside opportunities due to sheer work/life balance burn-out.

headline: They are only concerned with the accounts that have money.  They don't care much about the little people.

headline: Part time teller
pros: Flexible hours. Birthday off. Good health care benefits. No sales
cons:
Regional managers pressure bankers to get a loan per month if no they get fired. They're turning very corporate like. For vacations, you have to accrue your hours if not you pay it back if you quit before the end of the year. 
As a banker I thought I would get a better opportunity at advancing but I have applied at 5 jobs and I haven't heard from any of the recruiters.

headline: Things have changed.

cons: Unreasonable goals for a lot of employees.  Losing that community bank feel.

headline: Teller

headline: Branch Banker IV
pros: BB&T offers a very supportive atmosphere where every employee is given a chance to succeed and grow.

headline: BB&T -  The company that honors their CYA culture.
pros: $15 per hour entry level. Benefits begin immediately.
cons: CYA culture, like I've never seen before. Uneven application of rules and regulations. Favoritism. Hostile work environments. Good Ole boys club. Bank Managers with no college education, lower salaries. Age discrimination. Support of bullying in workplace. Peers stuck in the "its not my job mode." High school click mentality amongst grown people.  Ethics hotline useless. HR investigations favor leadership no matter what evidence you provide. Best to seek outside legal advice. These folks have been at it for some time now. Employees are stuck because of the nice hourly wage and benefits. Can't leave, and endure emotional and verbal abuse on a daily basis. People afraid to come forward for fear of losing their jobs or being in hostile environments. It's a terrible culture and place to work, and it's know. Just needs to be exposed at higher levels. Managers will keep you after work, with no notice, because THEY are available.

headline: Good Company Culture
pros: Company has great people and a good company culture.
cons: Pay seems slightly lower than comparable positions.

headline: BB&T
pros: On paper, this would appear to be a great company to work for. The mission and values are solid and any decent person would be able to relate to these ideals.
cons: It is a very "what have you done for me lately" kind of work environment.

headline: Doesn't value employees.
pros: Nice co-workers, some are welcoming. We struggle as a team.

cons: The downside is the shutdown of our call center especially since I played a part in making our center #1 out of all of the BB&T call centers.

headline: Do your research, discern the red flags and make a calculated move.

Cultural and relationship dynamics reflect subliminal racial discrimination displayed in team interactions, inclusiveness and group belongingness.

Employee expectations are not honestly communicated during interview process--such as overtime work and other circumstantial work-load.

Complaints are not handled confidentially and can threaten job security.

headline: Branch Banker IV
pros:
-It's a job.
- No other pros.
cons:
I never leave reviews for anything, but I wish I had known what I do now...

- Can't trust the company, false promises about job responsibilities.
- Employees are burned out and unhappy.
- Two people doing the job of the whole bank.
- You will work behind the teller line at least 20 hours a week as a Branch Banker IV.
- False promises of upward mobility.
- My manager was lazy and hardly ever there. I would have weekly meetings about improving my sales, never received any actual advice.
- The product isn't very good. Hard to sell a bad product that has a bunch of fees.

headline: Former Manager
pros: Good benefits, pay ok but somewhat low compared to market, great brand which has pulled the company along in spite of missteps.
cons: Confusion as to how the company should proceed in the future.  CEO is too disconnected from reality and what goes on below him.  In recent years a great deal of outside management has come into BB&T from other banks.  While this is needed some of them are to self-serving and political.  Community Bank has lost it's way and must be rebuilt culturally.  Credit Administration is sitting in the back seat now and being bullied by the field without support from their managers.  Many associates do not have the basic skills needed to succeed.

headline: BB & T not a community bank anymore
pros: Holidays , Vacation, benefits and maybe a rare bonus
cons: when I first started 13 years ago they were a great company but things slowly started to change over worked and under paid sometimes their would only be 2 people in a whole branch at times. Safety didn't seem like a issue lately just sales. People were leaving and getting fired left and right after being there 10 plus years.

headline: Horrible employer
pros: Great benefits and great pay
cons: Treat employees horribly, not consistent with schedules, not professional, feels like you are in high school, if you are not the bosses favorite then you won't get far

headline: AVOID! LOOK ELSEWHERE!
pros: The only pro is that you receive a paycheck and that’s not even saying much because they aren’t even paying much.
cons: Your typical good ol boy down south conservative company, no diversity in management!  Anytime a company says they have a CONSERVATIVE way of doing business, RUN! The department is ran by a bunch of incompetent child like individuals. You’re forced to participate in their kiddy activities. The turnover rate is extremely high and it’s not because people are being promoted so don’t believe that lie they feed to you in the interview. It’s because people are running out of the door and they don’t even respect this department enough to give them a notice. Every couple of weeks you have the pleasure of knowing someone is getting out of the sunken place! They all just up and quit and it’s very much deserving. The nepotism and favortism is ridiculous. There was a new employee who was on Quality Control for an unacceptable extended amount of time  which isn’t normal protocol.  Had it been anyone else, they would’ve been terminated. The employee wasn’t even qualified for the job but got it because of someone he knew who worked for the bank.  He even told the person that he wasn’t qualified for the job and he still received an offer.  I heard through the grapevine that said employee is no longer there which makes sense because his qualifications weren’t up to par to begin with.

headline: Business systems analyst
pros: Strong company with successful future. Love their core mission and vision. BB&T truly does live by their mission and vision.

headline: Disappointed
pros: The vacation time and holidays were great. I loved providing quality service for my clients. I miss the wonderful friends I made over the years.
cons: Worked there for over 10 years and lost my job trying to help a client the right way! Guess I shouldn’t have tried to retain a client. My manager didn’t even try to fight for me; I guess those days are gone. I find this very sad considering there are people still employed that blatantly did things that were unethical, but were praised for their wrong-doings.

headline: Full time teller

cons: Understaffed and terrible managers. Just a bunch of people with titles that walk around trying to act important! Loves to talk down to the associates .

headline: Family Feel in Corporate America
pros:
Folksy, salt-of-the-earth people-- from management down
Ability to take end-to-end ownership of projects
cons:
Company going through growing pains-- getting larger but mentality of small corner bank.
Not a market leader -- content to be a market follower

At the end of the day all pros/cons are about style. If your style is a slower work pace, being treated like family in a Southern environment, seriously consider BB&T. If you are looking for a fast-paced market leader with urban sophistication, this company is not for you.

headline: Disappointed
pros: good benefits and good hours.
cons: I recently lost my job after more than 32 years with this company because of an unintentional error. 32 YEARS of loyal hard work, sweat and tears. They say their are no 'sales goals' but the company just rephrases the expectations.  This is not the same company I worked for just 5 years ago. Associates are dropping like flies! I was a exemplary associate. I'm sadden by this. Feel like I'm getting a divorce after being dependable and loyal for many, many years. BB&T now expects nothing but perfection! 'non-negotiable' !!! The staff is expected to work with a very, very lean staff to reach unrealistic goals. Which creates disgruntled clients. Which means the tellers get the brunt of the client complaints of the long wait time.  BB&T is about the bottom line instead of how the client might perceive their banking experience.  Clients don't understand that with every banking transaction, the bank associate's job may be on the line. Something I took lightly which cost me my job.  I remember a time in my 32 years, where my manager would fight for me. I was shown the door...'NON-NEGOTIABLE'!!

headline: Market Leader

headline: Great company. Lacked support in the area for me.
pros: Great company but with the current market and regulatory environment it is hard to compete with smaller brokers.   Not very well known in this area.
cons: Commission only with small base. Operations Dept for mortgage did not operate well when I was there. Originating system was very complicated.

headline: BB&T
pros: Small bank mindset in a large bank
cons: Short term earnings focus, lack of strategic vision.  Penny-wise pound foolish.

headline: Overall, a good company to work for
pros: They start you with 10 vacation days plus 10 paid federal holidays off and give you an option to purchase up to an additional week of vacation. There's a free employee health clinic that's separate from you're health insurance. No copay or deductible, and they even give you free prescriptions. Of the banks that have tried recruiting me, BB&T has a higher base salary. The company minimum wage is $15! The department executives are very approachable.
cons: Being in a difficult branch can make it difficult to advance your career. No opportunities to earn incentive bonuses. Some of the processes are outdated. Also certain departments have zero diversity (I'm not sure if that's just by coincidence)

headline: Inadequate training, inconsistent policies
pros: It's a job and the pay was decent.
cons:
Unfortunately, although pay was decent, I was only PT, so I didn't earn enough to support myself.
Training for this job where you handled accounts and money only lasted 2 days.
Coworkers who were supposed to be supportive were rude and curt time (although they had plenty of time to chit chat with customers about their personal business).
I was hired right before the manager went on a 2 week leave, so I couldn't go to her for help
I was required to answer the phone while assisting customers standing right in front of me.
Customers were charged so many fees that they often asked me to do tasks that they'd normally have to pay BB&T for (such as rolling coins, printing account transactions & balances, etc.) I didn't mind helping the customers, but this made for long lines in the lobby.
Rules were applied inconsistently, which made it particularly hard for me as a new employee. One time a customer yelled at me, then filed a complaint because I would not allow her to withdraw $1300 from her account WITH NO ID WHATSOEVER. Instead of thanking me for helping to protect her account, I was punished for it. She said that the other tellers let her do it, so I should also. I had no idea if this woman was the actual account holder. (Who leaves the house w/o any form of ID?? Especially if you're visiting the bank!)
When I couldn't get anyone to help me if I had a transaction I couldn't figure out, I was reprimanded for attempting to resolve it myself.

headline: Work load and accountability on few shoulders.
pros: Autonomy, pension, other benefits, vacation plan
cons: Unhelpful management, heavy workloads, no accountability for poor performance

headline: CSA at BB&T

headline: Getting better
pros: Upper management is always helpful. Some good people to work with. 2018 minimum rate of $15 per hour. 6% 401-k match.  Stable company. Room for growth in movement to management or other levels as long as you have the education or experience.
cons: Your direct supervisor on the teller like may be horrible. If so it’s very difficult to work because your life is now a drama movie, where everything is a big deal. Workplace is a very fast environment. Clients often get mad about waiting in line. No music. Very quiet all day. A lot of stress. Never get home on time. They expect you to take extra time on your lunch break for when you run over your time at nights. They won’t pay overtime. They won’t let you progress from the teller line. It’s a fight the whole way to get more training. Responsibilities are not shared between Employees, so if you start something you’ll be doing it till you quit.

headline: Poor Management, Bad Decisions - avoid

This used to be a great company.

headline: Feast or Famine
pros: Fun job, love clients, easy work.
cons: Company doesn't seem to care about part time workers.  We are simply there to cover full time workers lunch breaks and vacations, and they have a lot of vacation time.  So on weeks no one is on vacation you get to come in a work a couple hours to cover their lunches and get maybe 10 hours that week.  Weeks full time workers are on vacation you may have to work 6 days and get close to 40 hours.  They do not explain this at interview.

headline: Bankcard
pros: Bankcard is a great environment to work in
cons: All the overall company cares about is profits and not always about what's best for the client/customer.

headline: Understaffed
pros: Professional atmosphere; several promotion opportunity
cons: Understaffed branches; no management presence; low wages, each employee works too many Saturdays; no time off; too much pressure on sales and referrals.

headline: Nice Environment
pros: Management was nice and willing to help. Benefits were good also.
cons: With the bank so concerned with profit, they regularly would transfer whole departments to different markets without warning. The work was time sensitive and training was more trial and error than consistent procedure.

headline: Quantitative Analyst - Funds Management
pros: One of the better places to work if you're constrained to the Winston-Salem area.
cons: I worked at corporate where the goal of upper management was to constantly impose a facade that everyone was "family".  Focus when interviewing new employees was not on talent, but instead individuals who were handcuffed to the area.  Lack in quantitative leadership at higher levels likely due to the political battles that were constantly being waged.  In my short time there two of my managers had been ostracized to be removed from the company or removed from positions of power.  Huge disconnect with banking needs of those currently entering the market.  Come on "The best of the best" as a motto?  Shady practices around compensation, skating around HR handbooks to ensure certain bonus payouts are not made.  Huge lack of diversity at senior levels.  Turnover rate is immense in specific department; ~1/3 of analysts either left their job or were looking for new jobs from my beginning to end.

headline: Expensive benefits
pros: Some good people with great technical skills. Ability to work from home. Solid company in the financial market. Diverse technologies.
cons: Expensive health care for family.  1.5 years before I would be eligible for bonus. No coffee or snacks. Dismissal office environment.

headline: Nice place to work
pros: Friendly work environment and people
cons: Layoffs occur without warning.  Unpredictable.

headline: Don't walk away from a  job offer...RUN!!! You've been warned!
pros: Decent benefits and mileage reimbursement.
cons:
Ridiculously low salary, 24k which is actually a forgivable draw.  

Really low commissions post DOL, which won't change back now that DOL rules have been postponed.  

Management, both upper and middle, that doesn't give a crap, and gives you absolutely no help.  

Extremely low moral inside the branches due to the high goals, low pay and lack of meaningful training.  Investments are simply not a priority.

Archaic technology that is glitchy  and is extremely convoluted. 

15-20 minute waits for client support.

Internal competition from private/wealth/Scott and Stringfellow, you are supposed to bring them referrals, but good luck getting any out of them.

No internal advancement opportunities whatsoever.

IC's are treated like throwaways, which is why the turnover has been extremely high.

This is a Annuity shop, based on the pay grid there is no way you can make a living building a solid book of business.  Most of the clients you will see will be well under 500k and are risk averse

headline: Bank Teller
pros: Great Pay, Employees are friendly
cons: Open Saturdays, no benefits if part time

headline: Branch Banker II
pros:
Opportunity to build relationship with community.
Lots of learning experience due to limited staffing.
cons: Always felt like management and  back office were confused when it came to how things should be handled. Sometimes sales would be more important than needs.

headline: Nice environment and friendly coworkers
pros: Friendly staff with good hours and very clean offices. Very easy to communicate with upper staff and colleagues. The office hours are fair.
cons: Not the most up to date systems. The systems for scanning your work to the back office is out of date as well as the drive thru systems in some locations

headline: Nice Company
pros: A nice company to work for

headline: Where developers go to die
pros:
The company has great benefits and pay.
Depending on your department you will have great coworkers and leadership.
Has decent stability and security, depending on your job.
Great flexibility.
Community events.
If you are just wanting a job to collect a pay check and aren't passionate about it then you'll do great here.
cons:
Company is stuck in the dark ages technologically.
Doesn't listen to advice.
Very slow moving.
Not willing or wanting to change.
Just talks without action (this could be the department managers and not executive management).
Hires incompetent people and won't let them go.
Only focused on numbers and what can be quantified on paper.

headline: Branch Banker I
pros: Strong sense of community among coworkers and clients. In house training. Growth opportunities.
cons: Often too goal driven. Inconsistent branch procedures/practices.

headline: Retail Banking
pros: Pay, hours, benefits, work-life balance
cons: Disorganized upper management

headline: I’ve been a part time teller(20 hours) for a little over 2 years now.
pros: Pay is decent. Benefits are available for part time positions, including health insurance, vacation, and 401k. Overall it’s not a bad job.
cons: Most of the time you will be understaffed and juggling several tasks at once. The worst part is the pressure to sell and make phone calls when you barely have the time and manpower to complete the essential tasks. Clients get very upset while having to wait because there’s only 2 tellers. No one is allowed to go over their scheduled hours. It’s very easy to get burnt out and stressed. That’s why there’s such a high turn over

headline: Customer Service representative
pros: This is the best call center I have ever worked for. They actually care about you as an employee and appreciate you. The manager is down to earth and knows everyone by name and even a little bit about you personally! Which is awesome. There is room to grow and after your grace period you can apply for other positions.  This call center actually wants you to stay unlike other centers who just use and abuse you until they fire you or you quit. I recommend this company if anyone decides to apply for customer service
cons: Only cons I can say is that they don't have a point system for abscence, it's "supervisor discretion" this is an unfair business practice! Someone can miss ten days and still have their job whereas another person can miss theee days and be fired if their supervisor says so! Therefore it sucks for the people who have supervisors that don't like them

headline: Good for shareholders, bad for clients and employees
pros: BB&T offers excellent benefits, a 6% match and vestment into a pension after five years. Advancement usually occurs from within. The company "allows you" to gift back a week of your salary for an additional five days of vacation. Training is intensive, ongoing, and thorough, which makes it a good company to begin your career in the financial industry at.
cons: Stress and helplessness. That is how your position will be defined, regardless of your title. Branches are staffed at such a minimal level that associates are constantly treading water. Associate turnover is incredibly high, all the time. Technology is embarrassingly behind for a company with such a large portfolio (8GB PCs!!). Clients are constantly unhappy with wait times and employee turnover. Sales goals are determined by some abstract process performed outside of your market and goals are expected to be met, regardless of how many vacancies are at your branch. Associate engagement and client experience are outwardly defined as the core of BB&Ts mission, but the reality is that shareholder profit is the only thing senior management is concerned with. Also, the company requires you to plan and submit your PTO by February for the ENTIRE year.

headline: Reconciliation Specialist
pros: Our CEO (former and present) have a great vision for BB&T.
cons: The vision of our CEO is not carried out by our management staff.

headline: Branch Banker
pros: Pay was good above average for local area.  Their Values system is positive.
cons: Constantly understaffed in multiple branches & all areas causing extreme stress.  Lack of proper training for staff & high expectations for sales.  High staff turnover.  Poor internal technology.  Money is spent in all the wrong places.

headline: Teller

headline: Do NOT work for BB&T if you are in the Information Technology or Information Security fields!!

cons: Internal politics are horrific!! Senior level managers only listen to those that brown nose them to a horrifying level. You need to have good health care to help with the dread and nausea you have when showing up to work every day. Any time I hear of someone thinking about working at BB&T , I warn them over and over as there is so much opportunity in the Raleigh area, there is NO reason to work in Wilson!! Management knows it's bad, and really doesn't care.

pros: Flexible work hours, good health insurance and vacation time. I’m able to plan my on schedule and meet with client at multiple offices.

headline: Manager
pros: Well-run, respected, and consistently profitable bank. High integrity organization with a very positive image in the financial industry. Above-average training and education opportunities.
cons: Way more Pros than Cons, but growth eventually changes all companies and BB&T is no exception. As a result, there is less loyalty to employees and greater pressure to reduce costs and headcount.  "Do way more with far fewer people and $'s" is the current mantra.

I wanted to yell at my manger for being such a racist B) another manager had a drug problem would boast about eating pills and banging younger guys. It is a step down but I am still expected to do what I did before but without the same abilities as I had when I was full time. My limits have changed and so has some of the access to some of the computer programs. That changes with job titles. So I really can not help  my clients to my full ability.

headline: Product Marketing Specialist
pros: Not micro managed, allowed to use full breadth of resources to expand the my position  to accomplish more than what is expected/ No set production goals, but always strive to outpace previous year's production through all methods of sales and marketing. cons: There is only 2 in the department which includes  department manager. Phone coverage is mandatory at all times, so It is difficult to both be out of the office at the same time.  Salary  plus bonus only - no commissions based on assisted sales.  Salary  currently under 60k - should be higher, and  personal bonuses have ranged from $3K to $5K which should be higher given the contribution to overall revenue.  Bonuses are not tied to anything , so you never know if one is forthcoming and how the amount is determined.

As they continue to grow, the continue to lose the foundation that built them. Product pushing and sales demands have now become the norm all while continuing to convince employees and clients we do what is best for the client

headline: Retirement and Institutional Services
pros: BB&T overall is not a bad place to work. Pension plan, 401K match, decent pay. Heath insurance perks if you are relatively good shape.
cons: Parking is not free in larger city's, this comes out of your pocket. They are super conservative and old school. Not a place for women or minorities to work. Only concerned with returns to shareholders, recent reduction of bonuses, incentives, reimbursements, etc. show signs of a company struggling. Not willing to spend money on technology to improve customer experience and increase work efficiencies. Most managers have no clue as to the amount of manual work their direct reports complete.

headline: Decent Employer
pros: Lower management is great. They are very helpful and always have their door open. Coworkers are also very friendly and everyone helps each other out.
cons: The work load varies by the time of year and can some times be unmanageable. If you are a hard worker you are often taken advantage of by being given a heavier work load, while others get away with a lower work load and taking breaks every hour. People that slack off are rarely reprimanded, which is very frustrating. Over time is occasionally offered, but they usually wait until everyone is so far behind it is impossible to catch up. There is very little opportunity for advancement and promotions are given as a title with no pay increase. With promotions you are expected to take more difficult files, but you don't get paid anymore to do it. Upper management rules with threats and rarely recognizes achievements. They turn what could be a positive enjoyable work environment into a frustrating and negative environment.

headline: BB
pros: Worked with a great group.
cons: Feel like I can't be myself

headline: Excellent Company
pros: great work environment and the employees actually care about their clients.
cons: not super competitive salary and compensation

headline: At least there's potential
pros: Benefits and pay are great (when you get them). Lots of internal support for when it comes to processes and procedures.
cons:
Hours are terrible. I was hired as a 30-hour employee and have averaged between 35-40 hours all year, but I'm still payed for only 30 hours on my vacation weld and I'm paid less than full-time employees on paid holidays. I've requested many times to only work the 30 hours I was hired to work and have been told that's not an option. Also, I was blown off when I brought up vacation and holiday pay. I was scolded for scheduling a doctor appointment when I finally had an afternoon off; I was asked to stay late and when I said I couldn't because of my appointment I was told that I should know better than to make doctors appointments during banking hours.

Aside from that, the culture is becoming very cult-like. There's a creed-like list of beliefs printed at the top of our daily action plan and management keeps referring to internal documents as our, "bible." We're constantly told that every client needs this, that, and whatever and if you question whether it's truly in the clients best interest then you're coached on your sales tactics.

headline: Many processes need improvement
pros: excellent pay and benefits.  pleasant work conditions.
cons: many processes make it difficult for new bankers to get acclimated to the position.  easy simple fast is definitely not the case with loans.  no set career plan or path.  difficult to move up.  there are many processes that waste time and effort to fix simple issues.

headline: Don't recommend company or position
pros: Their are great people you get to work with at BB&T - you will have the chance to build great relationships with colleagues!
cons: The @Work management is absolutely horrendous! The @Work leader hires managers who have little experience, no idea how to manage a team, and are overall pretty incompetent. It was a shame when I consistently asked my manager for feedback so I could become better and was only told "you're doing great" with no constructive criticism. My manager was an embarrassment to the region and I continually had to field calls from other internal partners complaining about their "leadership". When I was faced with obstacles or challenges, my manager kept telling me he'd get it figured out but would do absolutely nothing. I realized after a while, my manager was pushing his own agenda - and it wasn't in the best interest of the company. After just two years in the role, I began to hate it but stuck it out in hopes of things getting better. The program is a joke and the company preaches work life balance but then wants you to do 5am presentations, networking events at night, and work on the weekends. Take my advice - run and don't ever look back! I regret having wasted so many years in a dead end job. BB&T pays much less than other banks and after leaving, I was able to get a six figure job where I'm actually challenged and appreciated.

headline: Excellent early career track, but stagnant once in middle management.
pros: BB&T provides great benefits, high-quality people, exposure to many aspects of financial services industry. Ability to advance early in one's career.
cons: Too much micro-management, not very entrepreneurial or tech savvy, not very intellectually challenging, little decision-making authority outside executive management team.

headline: Market Leader
pros: Cost of Health Benefits if you are only insuring yourself are low.
cons: Gives unrealistic SALES goals; although publicly states they do not have Sales goals. They do not understand the new areas they are in. You do not have any support from back office or upper management.  Management from North Carolina has no problem swearing at employees in meetings; very much employ bullying.

headline: Branch Banker
pros: Teamwork, great benefits, and opportunity to move up
cons: Needs better organization of personnel and more consistent policies

headline: Great place to work
pros:
Senior management is caring and receptive to feedback
Good work life balance: Work hours are not too long
Employees tend to stick around longer
cons:
Not enough challenges. 
Not enough career opportunities. Compensation lower than the industry average.

headline: Mixed Emotions
pros: Insurance, 401k and pension are good benefits
cons: Terrible staffing at the branch level, not enough pay for the amount of risk involved

headline: Review risk for acceptability for insurance coverage.  Issuance of binders, invoicing and policy issuance.
pros: Good corporate culture. Good communication of ideals and employees expectations.  Works to improve processes and technology. Good people honest and sincere.
cons: No significant raises. A bit impersonal no quantitative methods for measuring improvement Too large. Nobody minding the "store".  Market share is flooded.

headline: Look to other financial organizations...
pros: Management maintains a very conservative attitude.
cons:
Loyalty and hard work is not always recognized.
Experience and time served does not matter during staff reductions.

headline: Overall good company to work for with proven track record of success.
pros: Good employee benefits including a pension plan in addition to a 401k match up to 6% and medical plan discounts based on wellness.
cons: Career BBT employees receive preferential treatment and considered more credible than  new employees or consultants with experience and expertise from somewhere else.

headline: Personal Banker
pros: They have great health benefits.
cons: The incentive packages are not as good as they used to be.

headline: Team Leader
pros: BB&T has the best interest of their clients first. They want their clients to achieve economic success and financial security and they give us the tools and training to help them do that.
cons: I can't say anything negative. I've been with the company over a year and still love my job.

headline: Branch Banker IV
pros: Hours, pay is decent, get your birthday off along with bank holidays.
cons: Limited opportunity. Since it operates as a community bank its all about who you know not what you know.

headline: Good Starter Job
pros: Room to move up in company.
cons: Sales driven model. Leaves little room for true customer interaction.

headline: Branch Banker III
pros:
-Great benefits
-Good culture
-Easy work life balance
-Fun environment
-Good for people who like to talk
cons:
-By the book on everything
-Authoritarian 
-Deadlines 
-Quota 
-Hiring based off of who you know

headline: Great company
pros: Great team willing to work together
cons: Typical corporate issues - resistance to change; politics; etc.

headline: No bonus, no motivation
pros: Great benefits, room to move up
cons: Took away bonuses, inconsistent training,  no communication

headline: Branch banker
pros: Nothing to say it
cons: They don't see your performance they rather give it to extrangers . Favoritismo is always on even if you do a great job but if I was not friend we rhe big boss you will never move on

headline: Branch Banker 4
pros: Great, friendly associates. Long-standing bank. Secure and stable.
cons: Sales goals high for the client interest in the bank. Very short staffed branches. No incentive pay for sales.

headline: Working with BBT
pros: I loved this company and the things it has to offer.
cons: The coworkers are usually friends of someone who is in charge.

headline: Nothing ever changes
pros: They are good about closing for snow.
cons: I've been reading reviews that I thought were recent and they are 3 or 4 years old, but they are the same issues.  Understaffed branches, ridiculous sales goals, though now they are called "quality consultative conversations " but the motive is still the same...SELL ANOTHER CREDIT CARD.  It's very hard to have the time for those conversations when there are only two tellers on duty at a time.   Forget any kind of a bonus or raise because between the high goals and the fact that the audit reviews knock points off of your "score" for such important things like putting a check instead of an x in a box, or initialing a report instead of signing it, or forgetting to stamp it, one has as much chance of meeting the matrix as winning the ring road at a carnival.  The scheduling is horrible, one day off in 12, usually three 10 hour days a week, but there is no overtime, so you constantly have to enter less hours than you actually work to keep it under 39.5 per week.  You are micro-managed to death.  This place will burn you out in a matter of months.  Obviously, since these are the same issues that were mentioned years ago, management couldn't care less.

headline: Business Analyst
pros: Steady organization that takes care of its people
cons: Limited growth opportunities and no training is provided

headline: Great at first, left due to management changes
pros: good coworkers, great benefits, opportunity for advancement
cons: branch level management was inexperienced, would have had a better experience under a more professional manager.

headline: Benefits
pros: Clean environment, friendly people, decent benefits
cons: Micromanagement, inadequate training, unprofessional

headline: Teller
pros: BB&T offers many Benefits for employees
cons: Not enough room for growth unless your are in NC.

headline: Branch banker 2
pros: Ok pay. Holidays off 9-5
cons: They claim there's opportunity for advancement but they're very deceptive in their promotion process. I don't know if it's Bbt as a whole but definitely is the case in East TN. The managers keep their employees in the dark there is little to no training it's kind of a sink or swim kinda thing. The employees under management actually train management because of this. Bbt will hire outside of Bbt before they hire from within. Then other employees are stuck training their "manager". Bbt is very fickle one minute they want one thing the very next minute something completely different. This business is very unorganized and dishonest. Probably due to the lack of properly trained management. Clients get very frustrated with the  turn over. I have been with Bbt for 2 yrs and have had 4 management changes and are now looking for the 5. These people they hire have no previous management experience and some have little to no banking experience.  Furthermore all the branches are under staffed so if there is someone out on just vacation it's a scramble to get any coverage for a simple lunch let alone if someone calls out. The employees are overwhelmed and feel used. They ask you to work on things above your pay grade to be a "team player" yet when it comes down to it they're just using you until they can find some other tyrant that has no clue what they are doing. Sick time unless your foot down they will take advantage of your kindness. If you're sick or have someone die in your family might as well just stay home don't try and be sweet and torture yourself till they can find coverage because they will convientley not find coverage and make you feel even worse for leaving just to go to the doctor or a funeral. Oh and don't have a miscarriage because they will ask you almost daily after having your doctor's note when you will be coming back.

headline: Standard
pros: Opportunity for advancement is there. It can be a great place to retire. They offer decent paid time off, pension.
cons: Wish they offered student loan repayment in exchange for services. Must be a banking officer for tuition reimbursement.  Have to move to advance further into the company.

headline: Engineer
pros: Steady dependable income from reporting to work.
cons: You get hired for one set of job descriptions and then expected to wear many hats for different job duties. Makes it seem like you are paid for one job while performing many,many more. And if you rebuke; you get "Below expectation" on your PDP (Progress reviews) by your manager. Very unfair tactic to hold down compensation advancement.

headline: BBT Bank
pros: Clients and company is very family oriented. Work environment is always clean and safe considering that it is a financial institution
cons: the downside of working here is that they expect so much from you with so little pay. growth opportunities are minimal

headline: Great Place to Work
pros: Good work-life balance and Great management
cons: Work is old schooled, limited career opportunities

headline: Struggles to progress
pros: Very stable environment. There is tons of institutional knowledge at BB&T. The company STILL has a pension and 401(k). Benefits start immediately. The pay is fair at the company. BB&T strongly pushes it's mission, vision and values consistently. The CEO stands firm on the values and he seems like a fair man.
cons: Benefits are expensive. Company has lots of employees who have been in place for decades which makes the company associates resistant to change and hard to advance. Many of my teammates don't even use instant messaging. It can be difficult to advance in some areas because those associates who have been in roles for literally decades. It's also a "gotcha" environment that breeds mediocrity. Ultra conservative and the company is a "follower". As an example the company's mobile app just started allowing (2015) mobile check deposits through the app. Most banks initiated that process many years before. Company has issues with diversity at mid and high levels of management.

headline: Accountant
pros: Great training was received on job
cons: Low bonuses - department never met sales goals.

headline: Branch Banker I
pros:
amazing benefits and great pay - even for part time compared to most banks in the area
work/life balance is very fair
excellent teamwork between back/front office
plenty of opportunity to advance for those who want to
relocation is generally an option
sales goals are based on branch totals not individuals (tellers)
cons: not on the west coast :(

headline: n/a
pros: Great company to work for.
cons: Mid-Low pay, internal advancement hard to accomplish.

headline: Loan assistant
pros: Loved working there great people
cons: None none none none none

headline: Risk Management
pros: Good environment, people and senior management.  Training opportunities and leadership coaching are available.  401 k plus pension plan.
cons: Salary is a bit low compared to industry.  There are limited advancement opportunities or ways to enhance compensation.

headline: Need benefits
pros: Hours are great. Part time tellers don't get holiday pay
cons: No benefits for part time tellers

headline: Great Company
pros: Great Company, good team, good benefits
cons: Outdated software, understaffed, underpaid employees

headline: A good employer
pros: Good benefits, good training, good culture
cons: I can't think of  any cons

headline: Good for now. Quality environment based on values and employees.
pros: Reasonable pay. Several opportunities to learn. Good people. Generally good clientele. 9-5 Mon-Fri, 1-2 Saturday's per month.
cons: Little creativity throughout the work day. Can be redundant day to day. Without regular reminder that the majority of clients are good, hardworking individuals, it might be easy enough to allow the handful of fraudsters to negatively bias the outlook of dealing with people.

headline: Good, inspired environment
pros: good environment, nice staffs, good benefit
cons: face-paced time constraint, busy, etc

headline: Bank Teller
pros: Good pay, good benefits and nice hours.
cons: I disliked my time working for BB&T very much. All my coworkers wanted to talk about were Donald Trump and politics. The banks are very understaffed, and very busy- meaning many angry patrons. All around, I hated going into work everyday.

headline: If you want a non-eventful/stable job
pros: Good benefits; decent pay; Monday-Friday job, Saturdays only  four times a year for 5 hours
cons: Short staffed; More floaters should be hired to cover employees that are on vacation.

headline: Branch Banker
pros: the company has great benefits, good working hours and offer holiday pay
cons: the company is strict on sales goals

headline: Teller
pros: Great Benefits, great co-workers, great hours
cons: None that I can think of

headline: Collections Representative
pros: Lots of benefits and great pay.
cons: Collections call center... clients always yelling and you feel like "the man" bacause you work for the bank.

headline: Consultant

cons: Sales Culture is much tougher, hits goals or find something else

headline: Branch banker
pros: Old school good old boys club
cons: No money and the managers blame u

headline: Great place to work

headline: Not bad, but not great
pros: Bonuses can be good.  Friendly culture below the management level.
cons: BB&T wants to be a big bank, but is still operating like a small company.  Lack of processes and standards have resulted in a lot of internal issues.  Executive Management is out of touch.

headline: Decent
pros: My coworkers were nice and friendly
cons: Next to impossible to move up

headline: Good place to work
pros: Great work/life balance with competitive pay.  They work with you to keep you happy and productive. Stable job environment
cons: Slow to change. Meeting all the time with little to no actions from the meeting.  Very expensive insurance plans.  Little to no training after initial training.

headline: Overall a good company to work for!
pros: Culture, Management, Co-Workers, 401K Match.
cons: Sometimes stressful, robotic sales approach, constant change of procedures.

headline: A Great Place to Work!

headline: Branch Banker IV

headline: IT Business Consultant
pros:
- 401(k) match is excellent
- Health Insurance coverage is reasonable and opportunity to participate in a wellness program can result in lower premium expenses
- Generally colleagues are great to work with and the conservative risk appetite has ensured solid financial footing over the years
- Onsite wellness clinic for common ailments with some free prescriptions available
- Work/life balance is generally good despite staffing levels
cons:
- Extreme cost consciousness has lead to bare bones staffing levels and lower morale
- Not always prone to promoting from within
- Culture has changed over the last 5 years from its rooted essence of a community bank that has its community and associates at heart.  Focus now seems to be heavily on shareholders with investments into associates diminished.

headline: Awesome people
pros: Great CEO  you are the best ever
cons: None this place is wonderful

headline: I loved my job but not my coworkers!
pros: Great benefits! Lovely clients! If you love helping people, this is the place to be! Corporate is very culturally diverse. They will work with you on almost anything.
cons: Dispersed branch locations (rural areas) get away with a lot of things they shouldn't be able to. BB&T leaves a very Christian environment that shouldn't be allowed into the workplace. It also encourages certain discrimination based on sexual orientation, gender, and race: all of which I experienced while working for BB&T.

headline: Financial Manager
pros: Good benefits. Flexibly work hours.
cons: Lack of communication from management.  Not good at dealing with no performers. Training is always cut.

headline: Wealth Management
pros: Great benefits lots of vacation
cons: super conservative and reserved environment

headline: Teller
pros: Great hourly rate compare to other financial institutions around the area.
cons: the upper level management should solve the constant staffing issues.

headline: review

cons: low pay, responsibilities increase daily

headline: Treasury Analyst
pros: Good Salary, great benefits, little to no drama,fair treatment,over 30,000 employees.    BB&T is a great company to work for and really care about their employees, customers and community.
cons: Not that diversified,not the most exciting industry.  BB&T needs to diversify the location of their support jobs.  If I want to relocate and stay in my support role I have to do it in Winston Salem.

headline: Great place to work

headline: Collections Representative

headline: Great company to work for

cons: Need to improve technology updates.

headline: Typical Bank Environment

cons: Very pushy on sales. Manager at Avenues branch is very rude and places blame. All branches are short staffed

headline: branch banker
pros: good benefits. only pro of working here

terrible work life balance
top dogs don't care about tellers

headline: Trust division review
pros: The benefits are nice. The biggest perk being job security. In fact, most people have been there for 20+ years. Salaries are less than competitive but low inflation in immediate area makes it manageable.
cons: The incentive was just taken away, I imagine the pension will be gone in a few years as well. Technologically incompetent, way behind their competitors. Company buys growth as opposed to fomenting it organically. Shareholders are number one priority.

headline: Banker

headline: Solid career opportunity to build expansion
pros: Good culture and loyalty to associates
cons: Very limited perspective on industry slow adopt of change

headline: Roving Teller
pros: Overall the best financial institute I worked for, the people were great and they provided more than enough training and coaching.
cons: Only 2 problems I ever had, first they did away with my position. I loved that position very much. It kept me fresh and confident. Second, once my position was dissolved they offered me a few different teller positions at a few different locations, all with varying hours. I chose one and ended up feeling very annoyed by the pushing of sales on accounts.

headline: Relationship driven bank with an emphasis on compliance
pros: BB&T is very involved in the community. The bank has some very intelligent people working for them. Upper management is outstanding and engaging, you can tell they care about their employees. The benefits are some of the best and BB&T honestly has the best online banking platform compared to the competition
cons: The bank has a lot of red tape. It is important to understand that one of BB&T’s top priorities is to buy other banks and they can only do this by maintaining their clean, solid image and reputation. This makes it difficult to help some clients. Approvals are needed for many things. The banks values are amazing and encouraging however, there is almost a fear-based culture that could make you nervous that you may do something wrong. The current computer systems are not state-of-the-art and sometimes can cause loan errors or other problems that negatively affect the client.

headline: Bank teller
pros: great pay, awesome benefits, flexible
cons: sometimes have to work at another branch

headline: Def not all its cracked up to be..
pros: In my opinion there are no pros
cons: they act as if you're a robot who can do 30 things at once

headline: Csr
pros: Behind the scenes and very quiet
cons: On phone all day being monitored

headline: Call Center
