cons: Hours suck. One full weekend off. Sometimes you have to work 6 days straight before next day off. Vacation can't rollover.

headline: Wealth Advisor
pros: Great training, excellent benefits, focus on client service
cons: Technology was not always progressive

headline: Goals Unrealistic
pros: Overall the bank is sound for community banking.  One of the best options the banks provide is for retirement and pension.
cons: Leadership's views on goals are unrealistic.

headline: Customer service
pros: Entry level  good first call center to start at for experience.
cons: Pay is not competive , work life balance expected to learn several skill sets with no raise

headline: Lots of changes
pros: Relatively simple banking job. Good benefits and vacation plan. Seems like corporate tries to care about employees. Good co-workers equals great environment.
cons: No real opportunity for growth. Co-workers can create a hostile workplace. Very branch centered. Lots of gossip. Too many changes back and forth.

headline: It was good experience for those that want to make a career in banking.
pros: Bankers hours. You get to have an hour lunch, off all the major holidays and you get 2 weeks of vacation time as a full time employee with the option to purchase an extra 5 days.
cons: It's kind of slow to advance from being a teller. My supervisor was not professional at all and immature. When I get a referral the branch banker got the incentive not the tellers. Expect to get shopped by fake customers who will grade how well you do at your job. You have to welcome everyone that walks in the door with a "welcome to bb&t." Like a robot almost. Doesn't come off as sincere at all. And expect to be treated like a child and micromanaged as well.

headline: GREAT
pros: One of the highest paying financial institutions to work for.
cons: Staffing sucks. Work/life balance isn't the best.

headline: Insurance Representative
pros: Great benefits is definitely a plus
cons: Slow Advancement for career growth there

headline: Soso
pros: Decent pay, great coworkers, some flexibility with the schedule and benefits started immediately which is a plus. Decent vacation time
cons: Poor management, unrealistic sales goals. Constantly understaffed and refuses to give overtime. Uppermangement is clueless as to what really happens in branches

headline: Branch Baker III
pros: Pension, hours, 401k, full benefits, they also offer a program to cover some of the cost of health insurance
cons: There have been no cons as of yet! Everything is great, this company takes care of its employees.

headline: Great Company
pros: They are very committed to their employees
cons: A little too hands on

headline: Great company with good benefits
pros: This is a solid financial bank to work for if you want a career in banking.  The executive management team is very down to earth and is concerned about the culture of the company.
cons: There is more need for advanced technology and there should be more women and diversity in the executive level of the company.

headline: Anonymous
pros: Most are great people to work with. Some really smart people working there, and some good benefits. Good flex time
cons: Overworked engineers, lousy raises, do more with less, cube sharing, micro-managing managers. High medical deductible, slow to get anything decided, then hurry up and get done no matter the cost to employees time or health.

headline: Decent Job
pros: Decent pay, great benefits, Executive management is great.
cons: No more incentive payouts, becoming more like Wells Fargo used to be.

headline: Great benefits
pros: Great benefits (pension plan and 401k match of 6%)
cons: Very conservative credit culture at the bank

headline: Need to update job salary caps

headline: Collection,  customers service
pros: Management, work environment, benefits
cons: Increase in Pay ,Sunday off

headline: Great Company but Branches are a tough place to be
pros: Company has great benefits!  People are great to work with and pay is fair.  Really starting to hit stride in Technology.
cons: Understaffed at all community banking branches.  Difficult to create a successful environment if you are terribly understaffed and relying on who you have to fill in the gaps.

headline: Test Lead
pros: Great company with great benefits; employee oriented; best of the best philosophy
cons: none I can think of

headline: Great company mission not followed by management
pros: Great benefits, What the company stands for is great.
cons: Did away with individual goals and incentive in my region that resulted in no staffing and poor management. Very negative and treated employees poorly. They offer training with no way to train.

headline: Unethical Managers
pros: Decent benefits provided to employees.
cons: Poor work/life balance and dishonest management.

headline: If banking is the industry you like then BB&T is a good company.
pros: A lot of potential growth in Texas. If you like banking then a great company with good benefits. Has training and employee recognition on a regular basis.
cons: I come from restaurant and was told my experience would translate well to banking. That was not entirely true but the environment is the opposite of restaurant.

headline: Great place to  work
pros: Very large employer. Lots of room for promotion if you work hard. Great benefits.
cons: Can't think of any.

headline: Decent job but you are just a number
pros: Holidays off, Health Insurance is good.
cons: Management is poor in the department I work in, expected to be at the office during bad weather even when the rest of the bank is closed.

headline: Good Company
pros:
- Work is challenging, but not demanding
- Decent work/life balance
cons: - Work schedule is sometimes long.

headline: Very slow traffic
pros: If you are looking for a position where you can sit down all day on the phone this is for you.
cons: I personally did not enjoy my time at BB&T, this bank is targeted for people with money then yet, most branches are located in low income communities where it is highly difficult to find people with good credit and high profitable businesses.

headline: Good company, Great benefits
pros: Great benefits, excellent peers, good work life balance
cons: Weak management, stingy salary increases, limited mobility

headline: Excellent benefits and culture
pros: The benefits are best here as far health care, vision and dental go. The on-site cafeteria is has Ann abundance of options. Also the company culture is amazing here.
cons: The only negative I have is that the elevators are always breaking down constantly. Other than that this is the best job I have every had and I'm not blowing smoke.

headline: Great Company
pros: BB&T promotes from within. BB&T has great values. Training is great. Matching 40-1k up to 6% Pension after 5 years of service. Has a Wellness program that provides discounts on insurance. BB&T also contributes to the HSA plan.
cons: Great company no cons for me

headline: New hire and excited with products and the restructured incentive
pros: 6% 401K matching, paid day off for birthday, great health insurance.
cons: I will have to get back to this one

headline: Market Leader

cons: Sales goals removed from all branch employees except the Market Leader/Branch Manager. Cannot hold your team accountable for results, only behaviors, yet if results aren't there for the branch it must be your fault for not have strong behavioral leadership.

headline: Good opportunity
pros: Helping out people is the best part
cons: Co workers are ignorant and rude

headline: BB&T Walks the talk
pros: Senior Leadership team has integrity
cons: None that I can think of at this time

headline: Terrible Management
pros: Health/life Benefits, friendly bankers, decent training,
cons: commission structure, management leaves every day running of the branch to the bankers without additional compensation, class based structure of employees, it definitely matters whom you know rather than what you know. The compensation structure with the added responsibilities to run the branch make it nearly impossible to earn a decent salary in many branches

headline: Excellent management training program, knowledgeable teammates, generally good working environment
pros: BB&T sets management trainees up with a great base of knowledge both in and out of the classroom and this leads to success. BB&T hires some of the best people in the business. The overall work environment is teamwork oriented and friendly.
cons: BB&T doesn't always listen to employees concerns.

headline: Great Place to work if you dont mind not getting the right tools for job
pros: great pay and benefits to start as well as vacation
cons: terrible leadership, micro managed and leadership needs to trust employees more

headline: Pretty decent place to work
pros: Great benefits and decent salary.
cons: Antiquated systems and slow processes.

headline: Good place for someone in middle of career.
pros:
Wonderful retirement plan. Good 401k and defined benefit pension plan. 

Senior Management makes an effort to connect with employees through video series, surveys, Q&A

Compensation is fair

Very supportive of community involvement either individually or corporate sponsored. 

Company is in favor of work-life balance (generally). 

Telecommute opportunities are available for certain roles
cons:
Large company problems (heavily silo'd, lots of red tape when trying to get things done)

Lagging behind in the implementation of internal technology

Compensation increases are often mediocre so you'll need to be promoted or move around a bit to get sizable pay raises. It's difficult for managers to truly reward high performers.

headline: Community Branch Banker
pros: Good Culture, Potential to move up,
cons: Alot of cold calls. Straight sales.

headline: Banker II
pros: They offer great benefits, provides a lot f room for advancement and it's a very innovative company.
cons: vacation time offered could be better.

headline: Business Development
pros: Can not think of anything position to say about them
cons:
Poor salary and benefits
Management would not permit job posting to another position within the bank

headline: SVP
pros: BB&T still has a pension.
cons: BB&T is not diversified at all.

headline: Teller
pros: Great morals and company values overall, good competitive pay.
cons: Depending on branch, your manager may only see everyone as dollar signs and push you to focus more on selling than helping with clients' needs.

headline: I have truly enjoyed working for BB&T.
pros: I've been here more than 5 years, BB&T offers excellent benefits. The option to "buy a week of vacation" comes in handy. I now have 4 weeks of vacation because I used that option. They offer vision, dental, health, 401K, and several life insurance options. I read a lot of comments about brain washing. BB&T does like a consistent feel throughout the Footprint so you can walk into a bank in Florida or one in Tennessee and feel like you got the same high quality service. When you work for a paycheck you are expected to the job & do it right. I've read a lot of reviews that say BB&T micromanages its employees. I get what they are going for, that consistent feel for the client. BB&T is there for you as an employee if you are there for BB&T doing your job right!
cons: Sales are the only way to move up the ladder if you work in a branch. Again, I understand this because opening accounts means more business. If you aren't impressing the management with the numbers you aren't moving up!

headline: IT
pros: work from home, good benefits

headline: Market Leader IV
pros: Flexibility pension plan 401k insurance

headline: Great Company to Work For.
pros: BB&T is a company that is extremely family oriented. All the managers that I have spoken with and worked for go above and beyond to work with their employee's when I come to situation outside of work that involve family. BB&T also requires there workers to take a 5 day vacation at some point throughout the year. This is meant to give employees an extended vacation completely disconnected form work to be able to rest and relax.
cons: BB&T is a company that in the resent past has acquired many regional banks. In the process of transitioning the new assets and personnel there have been times workers felt overwhelmed.

headline: Project Manager
pros: The company promotes a home/work balance and they believe in career growth.
cons: There needs to be checks and balances to make sure pros are steady throughout all lines of business

headline: Relationship Banker
pros: Pay is decent, work facilities are ok.
cons: Upper management are deceitful, and do not allow for independent thinkers.  Regional and Senior Managers are very petty and fragile if you happen to disagree with their positions.

headline: Great Company
pros: BB&T offers great Health and retirement benefits. Vacation time is average to the industry.
cons: The company is very traditional but they are improving.

headline: Sec spec
pros:
Great Benefits and flexible hours.
Team environment.  Company seems to care about it's employees as well as the community.   Terrific place to work.
cons: Employees are paid once a month.  Pay scales and pay cycles need to be updated.  Forces employees to manage money so that part is not a complete negative.

headline: Quick overview
pros: Good benefits, great vision and mission
cons: not all management follows the vision and mission

headline: Summer Teller
pros: Good experience, learned a lot about retail side of banking
cons: Branches were always short staffed, employees felt under appreciated

headline: Very good place for me
pros: I work part time for BB&T.  Since I'm p/t(20t hours), I do get benefits.  When was the last time a p/t person got benefits?  Not many organizations offer that. I love the flexibility of the scheduling so I can make doctor's appointments, etc.  We have a good group of people in our office,  so enjoyable to come to work.
cons: I can't complain about anything.

headline: Underwriter
pros: Nice company to work for
cons: There was a lack of growth opportunity

headline: Head teller
pros: I didn't have to work weekends at my location
cons: Not a lot of foot traffic, so teller referring was a little difficult

headline: Teller
pros:
Steady schedule
Pay starts at above minimum wage, usually between $12-13 an hour 
Decent benefits, such as vacation and sick pay. Lower cost health insurance and a 401K plan that matches 6%
cons: Incredibly conservative work culture.  Very fear based. If you are caught saying anything against the company or the way upper management handles things you are sure to be terminated. Incentives are now being taken away from the branch bankers to "decrease pressure of sales goals" but it's really just a way to save the company some money.  The company does anything they can to save money really, including NEVER paying overtime to employees unless the situation is DIRE. I have known employees to straight up lie on their hours to not include any extra time just so they wouldn't get in trouble with management.  The branch manager I had was often very strict and somewhat emotionally abusive to a lot of his staff, particularly his female staff. I've witnessed him making at least 3 employees leave his office crying.  We worked on the retail side and the branch bankers are made to feel incredibly guilty if they don't reach their numbers. I myself was fired halfway through my pregnancy, a few short months before I could take maternity leave, because a corporate investigator dug up some old private conversations I had with another employee about our personal opinions and disagreements with the company. Very "big-brother" like. They also make you memorize a brain washing sales pitch called the BB&T "value promise," which is an unnecessarily long speech about the history of the bank, our vision and mission, the products we offer and why we chose to work for this GREAT COMPANY! if we don't use this value promise to EVERY client that walks in then we obviously don't care about the bank or our clients. It's all big corporate brain washing, but I suppose many large financial institutions are the same.

headline: Amazing company
pros:
Great pay
Benefits
Great platform training
Great opportunities
cons: Lack of cross training tellers

headline: Overall, a good company to work for

cons: Inexperienced management, grossly understaffed, high turnover, security risks, and antiquated technology which forced us to use long processes to do simple tasks. Also, bank charges a ton of fees, which were hard to justify to clients who held a lot of money with us.

headline: Bank of the people. Really care about the customers well being instead of sales. The people working there are amazing.
pros:
Salary is above average for smaller bank. Benefits are amazing with a Pension. Matching 401k 100% of 6%.  Healthcare premiums are super low compared to what I am used to. Definitely opportunities to advance. You get vested into pension after 5 years. Calculation for pension payout is your highest salary average over 5 years times your years of service times 1.5%. 
Ex. 100,000 x 35yrs x 1.5%= $52,500 paid to you every year when you retire.
cons: Smaller banks have less foot traffic. Unless you like sitting at your desk looking at your computer all day. Tough to make sales goals when no one walks into your branch.

cons: Limited advancement within certain departments.

headline: Decent company, management sucks!

headline: Mainframe programmer analyst role
pros: BB&T is a solid company that is proud of being conservative.  It never had major trouble in the housing crisis, etc.  So you don't have to worry about the company being bought out or going out of business.  They also give out bonuses when you are at or above certain levels.  These could be quite nice.  It was not a high pressure environment.  Deadlines were usually movable if you had a good enough reason, i.e. someone to blame outside your group.  If I could have changed to a different team, I might still be there.
cons: Like most places, happiness is determined by your immediate manager and a couple levels above.  I was very happy with one, okay with another and the third is why I left the company.  After seeing some of the technology up close, I vowed that if I ever won the lottery this would not be my bank of choice.

cons: Male driven company, intense sales culture, lacks diversity in upper management positions, work life balance could be improved. Banking industry as a whole is working to be more efficient, but hasn't increased pay to match increased responsibilities

headline: Going down hill

Excellent benefits package
Match 401 (k) contribution up to 6%
Somewhat of a possibility for advancement
cons: Unfortunately,  BB&T upper management no longer cares about the individual holding the position, just the position itself. They used to be more client driven but are now more sales driven.

headline: BB&T
pros: good, solid, financial institution with conservative management.
cons: inadequate staffing, inadequate training and development.

headline: Corporate Information Security
pros: Health Insurance is decent, the good stops there.
cons: If you are in the IT or Information Security career field , this is the WORST environment you could possibly work in. The culture is toxic and the senior level managers are incompetent, and that is putting it mildly. The salaries are two to three times lower than the same positions in Raleigh. The building that houses IT and Infosec is horrific and in a rough part of Wilson. The raises are non-existent and they do not recognize advanced degrees as most of the managers don't even posses a college education. Their focus is certifications and not actual knowledge. If you want a place where you do not want to have to think and they way to move up at all is to kiss up to your boss then this rat hole is for you. They LOVE to tell people that the grass is not greener on the other side, however it's so much greener it's not even funny. Everyone I know that has left within the past few months, and there are several, have doubled their salaries so how green is that!!

headline: Private Advisor
pros: Great culture locally, questionable regionally
cons: Regional mgmt loses sight of being human. Bottom line numbers are all that matter

headline: Overview
pros: Values-oriented company with many opportunities
cons: None noted at this time.

headline: Manager
pros: It was a great company to work for an hour strongly recommend any one I know who this company.
cons: Lots of hours worked pay could be better

headline: BB&T Retirement & Institutional Services
pros: Great employee benefits structure, especially Employer Match on the 401(k) plan (up to 6%), and personal/family sick time, and banking benefits. BB&T also still maintains a pension. Very much a family like environment. The amount of knowledge you will learn about the area that you will be responsible for will be incredibly extensive, especially compared to similar positions at other companies. The values that BB&T holds are superior in the industry. It is a wonderful company and a beacon of hope in the beleaguered financial industry.
cons: Unit/ mid-level managers have entirely too much power. One bad manager can sour your entire experience with the company. If you have a dispute with your manager, the first person you have to address it with, by policy, is your manager, then their manager, who clearly will side with their often more tenured manager. You have to stay in your position for 18 months before you can apply for other internal jobs. The job training is also minimal, you will have to learn as you go.

headline: Ok place to work
pros: Good pay overall. Decent benefits.
cons: forced to transfer to different branch with no notice; long hours sometimes with no lunch.

headline: Client Service Agent II
pros: The benefits are good.
cons: The Account Executives are awful. The Client Service Agent position has A LOT of turnover! The pay is low and the headache is not worth it.

headline: Team Lead / Supervisor
pros: Opportunity for advancement, Work-Life Balance
cons: If you are in a call center, the corporate atmosphere is very "Walk on eggshells" to maintain your position.

headline: Be prepared to lead a stressful life
pros: there are none I can think of
cons: you will kill yourself trying to meet their goals which are completely unrealistic

headline: All good things must end
pros: 401k, pension, pay used to be good but now they hold back
cons: Management, upper management, extreme push for unrealistic goals

headline: Very unprofessional
pros: The pay is nice. Most of the people seem to be very friendly.
cons:
Training is very questionable. I went through a temp agency & was excited to get such a "great opportunity". I was put with a team leader who was, for the most part unhappy to have the responsibility of training me. That was nerve-wrecking for me! She would stop mid-training to go do other things. I spent about 6 days learning to navigate the system that took 4 days for me to gain complete individual access. Then, I spent half the day on the phone for the first time with my trainer on a splitter. By lunch 12pm, someone called her into a meeting. When I came back from lunch she came & sat with me again for less than than an hour & disappeared again. At this point I'm more nervous than when I began because my training wasn't at all consistent. Later she dumped me on someone else. The following day, this trainer gave me 5 worksheets to work on while she did work on her own system. By lunch, I got a call from the temp agency telling me they feel I'm "not comfortable'! I've NEVER been in any company that decides to end a contract after 1 attempt at training with trainee taking calls. Then nobody Sheffield to inform why I was being sent home. 
Nobody actually even spoke to me to inform me what needed to be done to get better with my calls since I'm new. Lastly, as I'm getting my things together & saying bye to my cube neighbor who was very nice to me, a really mean lady comes up to me & says "you have to leave!" & even rode me down in the elevator to make sure. This lady is the work buddy of my trainer, they go on all they're breaks together & both seem like the meanest people in the building. This was a HORRIBLE experience! No money is worth being treated like this! I felt they just needed some ridiculous reason to get my trainer out of doing her job. Then I felt ganged up on & bullied!

headline: Good Experience
pros: BB&T purchased National Penn Bank in 2016.  As with any transition there were positives and negatives.  The people in the organization were very nice and helpful.  The company treated the National Penn staff whose positions were eliminated very well and fairly.  They provided a good severance package and outplacement assistance.
cons: BB&T is very functionally driven.  Often employees in different functions asked for the same data and in other cases they were not on the same page.  In addition, most of their staff was task focused and often didn't consider their impact beyond their line of sight.  All good people trying to do the right thing and a good job, but not experienced or driven to think broadly.  This is not uncommon when working in a large company who is growing quickly.

headline: Reconsider your career start as Credit Analyst
pros:
You have a job, you're getting paid.
You'll become more detail-oriented***
You'll realize that you probably want to work somewhere else :)
cons:
1. Politics. Too much politics. You will not be promoted unless you join the politics. I've witnessed too many people promoted on politics and not merit. Also, someone who has no idea what they are doing will be promoted ahead as your Team Lead beause their cousin works at the bank :)

2. Robotic. The more robotic you are, the better. This department expects you to not spend time networking around people who are 3+ years ahead of you, but rather, you should be at your desk 24/7 adding to the production line. 

3. sCraps. This division gives you no foods, drinks, or any HR-coordinated events. Instead, they will give you more work and expect you to smile and ask for you. If you ask why we don't network or have more than a half day for community service, the answer is production! Even if the que is at 0 for the department of 100+ people, they will make you stay at work and want you to "act busy" for no reason. Makes no sense to me.

4. Failed leadership. This company preaches about leadership but you'll notice there isn't a single leader here. You probably won't respect your team leads after several months because (1) you know more than they do and (2) you get tired of being treated as a child. Your team leads will also remind you that they are "watching you" constantly, like children. Leadership is not promoted on merit but promoted on politics. You'll notice that you have a better quality and production than your peers but one of them will be selected ahead of you, not because of your attitude, but because they spent more time brown-nosing around. You'll notice the average team lead doesn't meet the department's requirements of production and quality but you'll notice they are promoted because of family and friends. Promoted based off networks, which they make sure you do not have a chance to network around! 

5. Budget. The imaginary budget. Management will always talk about how we have no budget but you'll notice that they take weekly team-lead lunches that are all paid for, includes appetizers, main course and desert. No wonder we have no budget. Then when it comes to promotions in a department of 120+, we don't have enough budget to recognize our associates? And don't get caught replacing the printer paper, you may realize we don't have a budget!!!***

6. Lies. During the interview BB&T will say your here for 10-18 months, flat out LIE. Our top analysts are stuck here 2-3 years because the bank will not allow you to apply to more than 2 jobs at a time. Ridiculous, I know. And then you probably won't get these jobs because someone else who knew someone else got the job you were applying for. I've applied for 8 positions, declined on all because someone else knew somebody. And I thought attitude, production, and holding 100% Quality was important?  sCrap!

7. I could go on, and trust me, this list can drag, but I'd like you to join the team and add to my current list. I honestly need to find a new job lol. This year we've never had so many of our top analysts happily leave the department. One guy was promoted to CA II and he left the next week, which is the best note to leave on. We keep losing strong analysts and replacing them with weaker analysts. Wonder why you can't retain your talent??

headline: Great Place To Work For

headline: Great pay, bad management
pros: Workflow and benefits are wonderful, salary was worth the drive. Great atmosphere and nice perks as an associate. No other pros
cons: Terrible training and management. When I first started I was told I had 20 sick days but my department only allowed 10 days, I was fired for using unpaid time off, and according to BB&T policy, associates can only use unpaid time off if there is no available vacation time and/or sick time.

headline: ML Underwriter III
pros: Company has good benefit package including 401K, insurance coverage and pension plan.  Flex hours to a degree.
cons: Very unorganized management team.  Inconsistent management where managers do not even know 101 underwriting.  Very overworked with extremely long hours and their method of "acknowledgement" is to allow you to wear jeans on Friday.  Too sales and volume driven with no focus on quality loans.  Appears BB&T is headed down the road where banks went in the great crash back in 2007 and 2008.  Managers push and push the employees, but do not jump in to help the employees out by helping to underwrite, clear loan conditions.  If they choose to do so, they are very critical of the underwriter's work but in turn these are the same managers who do not even know the basics of underwriting.

Management desires to swim upstream or attain larger accounts, without hiring the support maintain the current accounts.  Position covers 5 jobs in 1. I feel i am underpaid over worked.

headline: Mortgage Lending Underwriter III

Also, her minions played the same tactics. I wouldn't work at this place ever again if JESUS said it was my ticket into the Kingdom of Heaven.  Prior to June/July 2015 I heard this place was a productive environment new management came in and the place is a "Operational Risk". Do not work here not an environment that allows candid feedback or open dialogue.

headline: Worse than originally thought
pros: I really can't think of anything,  There are quite a few paid holidays, but that is bank wide.
cons: They micro-manage you to death!   You drown in reports and logs and paperwork.   If you like working 6 days a week, not having any sort of a 'set' schedule, or not even being able to eat meals on any sort of schedule, being shoved around from branch to branch because somebody has decided that your branch is 'overstaffed' yet most of the time you are working with just 2 tellers when there used to be 3 or 4 on duty, (especially on Friday evenings and Saturday mornings, the most busy times!) having everything you do take twice as long as it should because the computer systems are so cumbersome and anything BUT user friendly, and having CYA logs, and checklists, and reports and documenting everything you do and AOOs scrutinizing everything you do, then this is the place for you!    If you enjoy being over-stressed, overworked, underpaid, and never appreciated, you will love this job.

headline: Stay away unless you can deal with heavy stress

They will tell you they are a community bank and care about their clients, unless the client is a wealth client, not so. You will drown in daily emails. Computer programs are out dated, procedures  wear on you, which make it impossible to service clients in a timely  effective manner. Employees are just number. Staff shortages in branches, employees will be expected to do the work of 3 people.

headline: Moving forward while stuck in the past by stepping on the employees.
pros:
Extremely large and diverse product and service set.
Seemingly competitive payscale.
Plenty of openings & availabilities.
cons:
"To Big To Fail" in a nutshell. Extremely similar to Wells Fargo in both origin and styling.
Constant mergers mean no stability or regularity on a regional level. 
Processes are extremely outdated and rigid.
Policy does not allow for adaptation depending on branch layout, staffing levels, market area, regional need, or special circumstances.
Branch network built around having few full timers who are required to work extreme hours, and several part timers who are expected to work varied and unreliable staffing schedules as determined by computer algorithm. 
Growth and advancement positions posted for extremely short periods of time, and given to individuals too quickly for many - if any - interviews to take place. 
Lack of cohesiveness and consistency across entire spectrum of departments.
No centralized support network. Several departments responsible for "support" often send employees back and forth.

headline: Improvements needed
pros: Job security is great. Health benefits are above average and the retirement benefits are average for industry. Corporate values are strong and important to all areas of BB&T footprint. Vacation and PTO are good (10 days vacation) (10 sick PTO days)
cons: Lower Salary compared to industry average. Minimal advancement opportunities. Lack of transparency between management and employees. Don't feel incredibly valued as an employee. Currently in a job freeze until early/mid summer.

cons: Not too many cons, Only just that it takes a while to get into a position to move up in the ranks.

headline: Banking on a Banking job with BB&T
pros: Bank Holidays in addition to regular holidays (except for Easter); with the right attitude and knowledge there is growth potential.  Large company with excellent senior management in place and lots of room for continued growth for the company.
cons: As the bank grows thru mergers, the workforce positions are being streamlined and or shifted to other areas to make the bank more efficient to handle the increased client growth which could lead to loss of job thru reduction in force measures.

headline: Just OK

cons: Low financial compensation, very low wage growth and limited opportunities for advancement.  Better place to end a career than start one.

headline: Collections

Great Benefits
Opportunity for advancement with many different avenues that can be followed

headline: Not for me

cons: Sales quotas, no room to grow in company, health benefits are ridiculous: expensive and high deductibles.  Training is done virtual.

Repetitive

cons: Technology is very behind the times.  Health insurance premiums are high for a family plan. Veteran employees not very open to new people right away. Very small raise yearly only.

pros: Great Compqny values and benefits.

headline: Great company unrealistic sales goals
pros: great health coverage, discount offered if participating in a health program. Everyone at the branch level is extremely friendly.
cons: micromanaged to attain sales goals, it doesn't count towards referral #'s if the customers that you are referring are declined (loans, credit cards, etc.)

headline: Accounts Payable Specialist
pros: Decent Pay, Benefits, 401k Match and one of few companies that still offers a pension plan. Good Work/Home balance.
cons: Very Political environment, have to know someone to advance. Hard work doesn't mean advancement and little to no work goes unnoticed by management. Bad for morale...

headline: "Worst Bank in Town" StayAway!
pros: The only pros are the benefits and pension plan.
cons: Everything else. Micro management with unreasonable sales goals. Terrible work schedules with limited branch staff. AOOs are constantly badgering bankers. BB&T has the worst training in the financial services industry. It's virtual "training" with no support. Finally, the salaries at BB&T are not competitive-at least $5K-$10K lower.

headline: Former Employee Review
pros: Acquired Susquehanna Bancshares and was helpful in finding a new job and keeping us informed, when necessary.  Nice place to work.
cons: Could not always answer our questions during acquisition.  They have been through many acquisitions and should have been able to answer the questions, based on previous acquisitions.

headline: Branch Banker
pros: Good benefits, pays higher base pay than other larger banks
cons: Extremely understaffed, no support from upper management, little to no growth opportunities.

headline: Worked with great people, the bureaucracy was sometimes hard to deal with.
pros: Great benefits. The people I worked with were great. Pay was comprable to similar jobs. Even sales referral bonus opportunities exist.
cons: Bureaucratic nightmare. As with many corporations, even the most insignificant decisions had to be forwarded to the main office for approval.

headline: Good

headline: Investment Counselor

headline: Branch Banker Team Leader

headline: Great if you have no other opportunities.
pros: Decent wages with competitive benefits. Attempts made to have an ethical culture through pseudo-philosophical training. Training given on a semi-regular basis.
cons: CEO down through management have no issues lying to employees. Employees routinely work without meal breaks or sufficient staff to perform assigned tasks. Sterling Award system is popularity over merit of  employees. Opportunities not given for internal advancement, but instead outside hires are often brought into the company for lower benefit expense.

headline: Great culture
pros: Great values-driven culture. Associates are recognized for their contributions.
cons: Several years of tough expense control weighs on morale.

headline: Good company with good culture

headline: Teller

cons: Job advancement could take several years and may require relocating to a different branch.

headline: IT Operations
pros: Decent overall Compensation, could be better
cons: Expectations on employees is very high at times, do more with less mentality

headline: Former employee

headline: Teller Supervisor

Each branch, not region abides by different rules, and upper management is clueless. Operations officers tell incorrect information, and later give employees exceptions for the incorrect information they gave. There is minimal opportunity for growth unless you are in North Carolina, which is where the home office is located.

headline: Steer Clear
pros: Pay was OK. Benefits so so. Scheduling sometimes good.

headline: N/A

headline: Operations Center

headline: Teller

Very high goals, not impossible but hard to reach.

headline: BB&T CCA Review
pros: Office environment was generally positive. Team members worked well together to achieve goals, both among peers and team leaders to peers. Bank benefits and employee support. Compensation was very fair for the role I was in.
cons: Only comment contra to the above was there was a bit too much micro management on my particular team for professionals who had 10-20+ years' banking experience.  While experiencing  improvement, IT/Systems at BB&T is a bit behind the curve for a $200B bank.

headline: Developer
pros: Very friendly working environment. Work life balance is good. Love working here.

headline: BC Loan Ops Processing Specialist III
author_position: BC Loan Ops Processing Specialist III
pros: good benefits, flexible, nice people
cons: pay is subpar based on the work load

headline: Teller
pros: Great company. Solid ethics. Good pay, good benefits. Well organized.
cons: They have a general rule that you have to be in a position for 18 months before getting promoted.

headline: Branch Banker IV
pros:
-401(k), 6% matching

-Great health/dental benefits

-Base Salary (If you're a top performer)

-Majority of the in branch staff are awesome people to work with

-Great Opportunity to get your foot in the door in the financial industry, and get sales experience
cons:
-Staffing is atrocious, many days were spent with myself closing with one teller, while handling lobby clients, clients on the platform side, as well as two drive-thru lanes in a branch that has very heavy foot traffic

-Constantly having to deal with AOO's breathing down your neck giving you audit exceptions or giving you a hard time for not have part of a log or sheet of paper filled out with the right wording that they feel is fit. While knowing full well, that you're doing the job of 3 people, and don't have tons of time to sit out and fill out 4 different logs for one thing. 

-Total disconnect with upper management, they will require you to be on multiple conference calls every week that you really have no need to be on, while at the same time you have to leave you're staffing out to dry because you have to be stuck in a room on the call and can't help any clients. They will also change goals, strategy, and focus about every two weeks, which makes it nearly impossible to every see a strategy all the way through.

-They constantly preach doing what is best for the client, this is not true at all. They're a big bank folks, they're here to make money. Those who get promoted are the ones that sell the most products and bring in the most revenue, once I realized this it made my job a lot easier and allowed me to perform better. Get them to sign on the dotted line, then on to the next one, once you can no longer sell them products they are no longer of use to you. This is real churn and burn banking.

-They will not pay you a decent wage until you have really proven that you are worth losing, I was under paid the majority of the almost 3 years I was there. It wasn't until I was a top 10 performer in my region for an entire year straight, and got another offer from another bank did they offer to give me a tremendous pay raise.

headline: The Journey
pros: The hiring process was fairly easy. They fingerprint and run background checks just like any other bank.  401K,  2 weeks vacation,.
cons: Its definitely an old boys club there, no new members allowed. If you do too much they feel intimidated, but if you do to little, you get disciplinary actions taken against you, so you have to find a balance even if they give you a huge work load. The managers in that department are unaware of their associates duties and their own because their training is poor. Nothing is documented, everything is a lecture, mostly via conference call from the associate that does the job or previously did the job. Often times they purposely leave out important information that would aid with the your job.

headline: Complex Manager
pros: Most of the general staff was great
cons: Many..probably the result of being at a " satellite" office. Communication was terrible

headline: branch banker
pros: the work hours are great! you also get incentive on every bank product that you sell.
cons: Terrible management. The MLs are fake and insecure. They are constantly finding something that you have done wrong. Lost of fake people with in the org. no one likes what they are doing because clients get mad all the time.

headline: Branch Banker
pros: Somewhat flexible, benefits, networking,

headline: MLO

headline: Anoynmous
pros: Hours - benefits are decent.
cons: Welcome to 1950! Where sexism exists at it's finest. Oh and unless you are "young and energetic," don't expect to advance. I had a Bachelor of Science in Finance, was with the bank 5 years, a high performer, and a man (younger than me) who had no college degree, less experience than me, and was not already working with the bank landed the position instead of me. This bank will be sued one day if they haven't already.

headline: hard to advance and wrong people in management

headline: Stay away!!!!! RUN!!!!
pros: Stay away! Run! Stay away!!!!! Run!!!!! Bad bad bad environment backstabbing, stealing, corruption, underhanded politics all day!!!
cons: Stay away! Run!!!!!! Backstabbing, stealing, corrupt underhanded politics all day!!! Deceitful!!!!! Horrible!!!!!! They will screw you over!!!! If you are not an established favorite you are literally treated as trash!!!

headline: On The Move
pros: Great atmosphere and people to work with.  Fantastic 401k and pension!  Ablility to balance work and personal life.  Not micro-managed by supervisor.

headline: No devil
pros: You get to dress casual.  And that is about it. This company is a mess. Run do not pass go do not collect $200 RUN. BB&T might be a good company but Regional Acceptance is not. Do not be fooled. The turnover rate is ridiculous. Put in an application at Chick-fil-a!

headline: Bank Teller

headline: Teller
pros: Meeting clients and building relationships. 401k and benefits. That's about all I can say that is positive in that place besides having the holidays off.
cons: This place does not care about their employees. $15 gift every Christmas to eat with and if you don't go eat with your office then you don't get the $15. The incentive program is a joke. If you don't meet a certain dollar amount then you don't get any of the money you worked for. Everyone is a number and this company is becoming greedy. Used to be a good place to work for but their customer service opportunities are awful.  The raises in that place are pathetic. Maybe 20 cent a year if your lucky.

headline: Great Company, Poor on Staffing

cons: Banking is a constantly evolving industry. Staffing has been cut thru attrition and turnover to fit into business model of every one is a Universal Banker. Less staff, higher responsibility, more stress. Company is becoming EXTREMELY sales driven instead of service driven. Also new hire training has recently been revamped and is extremely poor.

headline: Senior Teller
pros: BB&T tries to keep a small community feel, despite growing rapidly.
cons: BB&T does not seem to care for the well being of the associate. The pay seems to believe below industry average, there is little upward mobility available and training is not always efficient.

headline: Retirement

headline: Retirement

headline: Branch Banking
pros: The variety of work that I am able to do within the branch

headline: BB III
pros: They offer a very competitive product set.  Which enables Bb's to offer something to every customer.   Good benefits if you can get management to tell you what they are.   Executive management has a clear vision and plan for the company.  They are executing nicely.
cons:
Almost non existent sales training.   Archaic  computer systems.   The simplest task requires accessing multiple systems.  When employees need help it is common to be on hold with back office for forty minutes. Sometimes longer.

Insane levels of management.  Absolutely no consistency in operations. Everyone does it different.  AOo's do their best, but once they leave, seasoned employees go right back to the way they want to do it.  Or don't do it at all.  

The level of favoritism and nepotism is off the charts.  It's truly a good ole girls network.  When a problem appears it's always your fault never the manager.  Zero accountability.

Bonuses are ridiculously low, better off not selling and helping the least possible amount of customers.  Less stress for the same pay.

headline: Stay away from BB&T in Wilson NC

headline: Teller
pros: I wouldn't know. I was only there for the two week training period.
cons:
The online training was tedious and mundane, but it was semi-helpful. (I'm a kinesthetic learner, not an auditory/reading as someone reads to you learner).
The in person instruction was abysmal to say the least.
I was poorly mismanaged and trained. The TS was going to put me on a drawer, on a Friday, on the first of a month, without properly training me. When I brought up my concerns she told me to suck it up or I could walk. I walked. I've been told by another branch that I bank at that some of the things she said to me and the way she treated me could have been a possible lawsuit, but that's not the type of person I am.

cons: Continual down sizing ( ultimately my reason for separating) and maximizing efficiency,  Didn't like it, but had to do what they had to do.

headline: sales

cons: Not enough pay for the stress and the patience needed to successfully handle this job  Excessive turnover, leading to stressed employees who are left to pick up the slack.

headline: Working at the bank
pros: It was a miniature family setting because it was the Op Center. For the most part, everyone got along well together. Most supervisors were helpful in helping you to succeed and with that comes trust. Overall, I enjoyed my many years there.

headline: Business Service Assistant

headline: Teller

headline: Banker
pros: Sought full family orientated company, goal driven minimal sales pressure. Results of sales tracked and pay is $1 for $1.
cons: Requirement to step out into the community and retrieve business on a warm lead. Sales plan can seem unrealistic in some aspects.

headline: better for people without children

headline: Vault teller

headline: Teller

cons: Working environment greatly dependent on coworkers and manager's management style, which can be a toss-up in terms of location you are placed at. Also, industry is changing such that all are required to sell, sell, sell.

headline: IT Consultant

headline: Prepare Yourself for Burnout
pros: If you have great coworkers, they'll work with you and help everyone succeed.  If you have great clients, they are a joy to work for.
cons: Micromanagement.  Not enough pay for way too much work.  Stress runs rampant.  Excessive turnover, leading to stressed employees who are left to pick up the slack.

headline: Age & religious affiliation discrimination
pros: No one looking over your shoulder all the time. Got 2 raises while there--had to ask for them.
cons: Worked long term full time temp for over 6 years. I was never hired by BB&T. Manager hired & gave special attention to employees who went to her church. More concerned about quantity than quality. Atmosphere was noisy with a lot of socializing (had to wear earplugs). Many who worked there ignored me. A few were nice. The boot-lickers were the ones promoted. May not have been hired due to my age (63 when I left) or political affiliation. New hires were paid more than long time workers. As higher pay was given to new hires, workers already there did not get raises to their level.

headline: Project Manager

headline: Certified Client Services Specialist

headline: Senior Teller

headline: New to BB&T

cons: Heavy emphasis on risk avoidance, somewhat averse to new technology and change, can tend to feel very bank-centric even if you are in a completely different line of business like insurance.

headline: Prejudice
author_position: Business Loan Administration Credit Analyst I
pros: Benefits, steady income,  biweekly pay. The outside vendor opportunities for discounts.  If you are in the in crowd,  opportunities for advancement.
cons: Prejudice, promotions based on affirmative action. Stuck in a dead end position. College grads make more than seasoned vets.

headline: Senior Teller

headline: Human Resources
pros: Great Benefits.  Reasonable pay.  Quality people.  Good Reputation.  Solid company that will most likely survive for some time to come.  Growing mostly through acquisition.
cons: So bottom line focused that often employee needs are ignored.  It is an "all-in" mentality that requires allegiance but that does  little to promote true teamwork.  So structured in the old school Jack Welch method of bottom 10% must go and the outdated performance evaluation system that often true talent is not recognized.

headline: poor management

headline: Branch Banker

Great culture as well as partners.

awesome benefits

headline: review

headline: Expect too much for too little

headline: Bank with an identiy crisis
pros: Company provides time for all associates to volunteer in the community. Health and retirement benefits are above industry norm. Opportunity for advancement is excellent, but only if you went through their management training program.

headline: Senior teller

I have been there for a number of years and have been dicouraged and passed over for positions that I am qualified for.  The company is GROWING BUT cutting the benwfits and hours of LONGTIME employees

headline: Credit Analyst
pros: Great entry positions out of college
cons: If you do not like cube life, welcome to it

headline: I chose to seek employment with BB&T
pros: Executive management is highly considerate to all employees at all levels of the company. They listen to what we have to say and meet with branch level employees to hear what feedback we have to give.
cons: Workload balance is very stressful

headline: Large company with great benefits, lacks personal interaction with support
pros: Great benefits, growing through acquisition.
cons: Very set in ways and procedure-driven.  Lacks personal interaction with support services like HR and IT (call 800 number).

headline: Market Leader III
pros:
- Great Pay if you are a top performer
- Your not stuck in the branch because you get to get out and develop business
- I left BB&T for a community bank and now regret it. Yes I was stressed but there was more opportunity at BB&T
- If you want a career as a branch manager then this is the place to be. Some branch managers make six figures. You will have to produce well though
- When I worked here I thought the branch support was horrible, now that I work at a smaller community bank I now know that BB&T has a great branch support system.
cons:
- If you work in the branch and plan to eventually go to the commercial side...Good Luck! I've seen it done but its very very hard to do if you have no commercial experience. 
- the annual bonus is not as good as other banks quarterly bonuses
- huge stress if you are underperforming. most of my branches were good but one of them I got had a lot of issues. It took me awhile to get it back in shape and the stress was crazy. The weekly conference calls were no fun because of the lack of sales.
- as with most banks and probably even most companies.....getting in good with the right people can get you promoted fast. It wasn't always about the sales.
- You can have a great year and think you will get your annual bonus and then BOOM!!! The bank decides to charge-off a bunch of your accounts before the new year and your matrix points fall below the minimum and you have NO bonus at all. We are talking about $5,000 or more dollars GONE in a snap!!

headline: So far it has been a good experience. BB&T has a lot of nice and helpful people.
pros: New to bank. Not sure. They do have a good training university. The people are very friendly and helpful. Enjoy working with the team.
cons: New to bank. Don't know of any cons. Still studying the banks information on products and services. Similar to a lot of banks in the area.

headline: Working for them

headline: An ethical bank

headline: Challenging Environment for a Bank Growing
pros: Despite some of the changes over the years, benefits remain top-notch - good healthcare options, exceptional vacation and sick leave (though this policy is not enforced consistently enough from manager-to-manager, dept-to-dept, or LOB-to-LOB), one of the few firms (let alone banks) to offer a pension, and good enough 401(k) plan.  Salaries tend to be slightly below market, but the benefit package will overcome some of that.
cons: Tremendously different culture than that of 10-15 years ago.  The bank's growth to a top-10 institution has created a bit of an unwieldy animal.  Most roles now have multiple layers of middle management above them, which has started to dissolve what used to be one of the company's strengths - the transparency in decision-making, strategy, and outlook from senior leadership.  This is likely not a conscious decision of mgmt., but, rather, the unfortunate byproduct of a transition from a mid-size regional "community" bank to a top-10 SIFI firm.  However, as mgmt. continues to preach employee engagement, but, the further you get from Winston-Salem, the harder it is to see that engagement, it begins to sound disingenuous.

headline: Bullying and red tape galore
pros: Get to work on some interesting projects.
cons: At the Raleigh operations division, be prepared for someone to be in the hot seat at all times. Certainly, don't believe the open door policy of management or that they will  help you resolve any issues. As a top-performing employee (the only one to get a bonus several years in a row) who brought an employee conflict to management's attention (the person had taken credit for my work, and also created a hostile environment), I was told that although I'd gone above and beyond, the fact that I would have asked for help resolving this situation (there were actually quite a few of them, it is a dog-eat-dog world there) meant that I got no salary increase whatsoever. I was flabbergasted, to say the least. Things went downhill from there. This company's horrible (and often uneducated) senior management caused several good usability engineers to flee as soon as the economy picked up. I tried to stick it out, but it was causing health issues including all-over body pain and migraines. I've worked in difficult environments before, but this one is particularly inhospitable. Some people, no matter whether they scream, throw things, bully, whatever...they will be allowed to continue this destructive behavior.

headline: Excellent Top Leadership
pros: Great benefits, some really talented hardworking people, and excellent executive leadership. BB&T has integrity and does the right thing, even if doing something unethical could result in a better bottom line. CEO Kelly King lives the BB&T Values. All but one of the Executive Management team members have been with BB&T for at least 10 years, and most of them have been there for more than 20 years. I think promoting to this level from within keeps the company culture and direction consistent and avoids "flavor of the week" strategies.
cons: Sometimes people in entry-level positions like Tellers don't get much recognition or many rewards, especially given the pressure they're under to make sales goals and given that they may be the only employees the general public sees. Also, when you move down the chain from Executive Management there are some unprofessional managers in the mix who will do or say anything to get ahead. Every company has a few bad apples, but the real problem here is that people who are good at what they do get by with mistreating and bullying other employees.

headline: Great company working to respond to a changing regulatory and competitive environment
pros:
-BB&T has a great culture and history of taking care of its associates. Your benefits will be good, you will not be expected to work any hours unpaid(if not exempt), and you will be treated like an individual with the ability to make intelligent decisions. In retail banking, this is not necessarily true of many large financial institutions. 
-Ample training - I received five weeks training before beginning to see clients and ongoing training after that
- Values - BB&T is a company that actually cares about its clients. The first time I discussed a fee refund with my manager, he literally word for word asked me what I thought "Was right for the client and right for the bank". BB&T is a for profit business focused on shareholder returns, but from executive leadership on down BB&T believes that    its focus in the market is helping its clients to be successful. You won't have to deal with shady consumer finance practices like retroactive interest, hidden fees, or the other sort of crazy stuff some other financial institutions do. BB&T's product offerings, while not always the cheapest, are not meant to be abusive or deceptive.
- Room for growth - BB&T is large and diverse with many different areas(retail banking, commercial lending, insurance services, private banking, etc) to grow into. Starting your career at BB&T provides lots of opportunities to grow both upward and to transition laterally if you realize a better fit exists
cons:
- Market Environment - BB&T is working hard to cut costs to provide competitive returns to its shareholders. This means staffing is lighter than most associates are used to and the bank has been repeatedly reorganized to promote efficiency. This is hard on the associates, but hopefully will translate to shareholder value and a more relaxed expense focus longer term
- Large Institution - I still happy bank with BB&T after leaving, and am exceedingly happy. However, while a larger financial institution has more width and depth of services, it is still not a small bank. Even with a customer service focus, there is less local decision making than at a small local bank with only a few dozen branches. 
- Conservative - BB&T is conservative, and very risk averse. While BB&T is currently extremely well positioned in its retail lending from a competitive standpoint, there will be deals you run into where we cannot lend because BB&T is simply to risk averse. Similarly, we will not charge prices that are likely to create long term losses on other services/products to generate short term revenue. This is great for the overall company, but may make it hard to compete with other banks willing to be more risky and short sighted.

headline: Corrupt politics at mid-level management lead company
pros: Good learning experience; compensated well for not doing that much; hours not bad; slow pace
cons: failure-fearing culture; hard word is not recognized; decisions are made based on politics; employees try to point out others' mistakes

headline: Great firm!
pros: Support and training programs are outstanding, solid benefits, advancement opportunities are provided, mentoring programs are in place.  Numerous career paths for ambitious, hard-working, innovative people.
cons: consensus driven organization, decisions can take more time. Cost conservative, like most reputable financial institutions - can make expense justification more tedious.

headline: High pay - highly demanding
pros: The pay was great  and the benefits were nice. The place had great culture, rotating around the perfect client experience.
cons: old system, constant system errors, outdated technology, cheap, pushy in credit card sales, and way too much drama for a bank. It's not an ideal work environment, and the system is extremely sensitive and error prone. Plus, they cross train their employees and set quota's that are IMPOSSIBLE to reach. The company has a great culture and atmosphere, but without updating to the current era (their system is 30 years old), they will fail.

headline: Not like it used to be, not good place
pros: The pros include that part-time gets benefits if work at least 20 hours/week. The pay range is about the same as other banks. There are still employees there that care about their work, the clients, and the success of the bank.
cons: The upper management don't care about the branch personnel. They say things like "if you don't like your job, there are plenty of people that are waiting for it". And "it's not all about you, You should wake up in the mornings thinking about your clients not yourself". There is no possibility for advancement unless upper management wants you to move, otherwise you are stuck. AND they now base salary increases on 'team production' not personal input... so whether you are a high achiever or a low do-nothing.... you depend on the branch success to get the same percent raise as the next guy (or not), so it doesn't pay off to work hard or care about your job.

cons: Technology is outdated and too many people are BB&T lifers who drink the kool-aid. Constantly changing priorities and too much nepotism.

They move employees around too much which makes the clients nervous. They have started moving away from their great mission statement and no longer are putting communities and employees first, it is all about the shareholders. If you make a big mistake you could be let go.

cons: It is hard to move up within the company, especially to break into management.  Company likes to promote from outside the bank which makes it hard to stay loyal because of the risk of getting stuck.  Raises are once a year and are usually very minimal.

headline: There are better Banks

cons: The rate of progression can sometimes take longer then other financial institutions leaving associates feeling as if they've been overlooked. The process for annual reviews/compensation increase are out dated.

headline: No room for growth
pros: Benefits were not bad, they still offer pension.
cons: no opportunity for growth. short staffed, moving towards 100% sales. vacation is 10 days for 5 years after 5th year you get another week for the next 5 years. there is definitely a buddy buddy system, you are either in the man club or your not, if you are in you will grow and have a lot of opportunity if not good luck! and managers, upper managers do not know how how to do any of the work they are asking the employees to do.

headline: Sneaky but productive
pros:
Productive environment.

Pay is better than most.
cons:
Management will crush you if you disagree.
Old school thought process.

headline: Mixed review as employee but a great place to be a client.
pros:
I enjoyed working at BB&T Wealth in re: my internal partners from Trust Ops., Commercial Lending, Financial Planning, Portfolio Managers, etc.

If you're looking for great Benefits, look no further.
cons:
Don't expect advancement or a promotion at age 45+ if you are a female... it's quite difficult.  You might find the atmosphere turns unpleasant.  Sort of a 'how dare you' attitude.  Most of the client facing key players in BB&T Wealth are in their 30's (mostly male and a few female); except management, most of whom are mid 40's - 60's and almost all male.  

They're salary offer will be a bit lower than you may expect... my suggestion ask for an extra week of vacation:)

headline: Going down the tubes
pros: Great people work in the branches, full benefits at 20 hrs/week, most clients are sweethearts
cons: Management has lost touch with reality in regards to expectations for sales goals.  The pressure is insane, and no one has the gumption to stand up and say "No, that's not realistic."

headline: Culturally lost its way

cons: The very values in which BB&T was founded upon are now almost comical.  Independent thinking, reality, justice, fairness are all values that employees were once required to embrace but now you ridiculed for.

headline: Teller

headline: Decent place to work

cons: very difficult to be promoted, hard work is not rewarded quickly, bonuses have been cut

headline: Hit and miss, depends on who is your manager and higher up.
pros: Decent pay, every holidays off, and easy job.
cons: Favoritism. Some regional and branch managers are great. Then there are terrible ones. If you get hired on, you will know right away if you got a bad seed or not.

headline: Horrible company to work for
pros: Off on weekends in Greater Birmingham Area
cons: The company thrives on saving money, but they work their employees like crazy by not hiring more help. There is not much opportunity for growth, and the company is very unorganized. Upper management doesn't take the chance to come out and visit their branches to see how the employees really struggle, and they make horrible decisions that affect the branches and the employees.  I would never recommend them to anyone unless they didn't have anywhere else to go.

headline: Relationship manger for defined contribution plans and retirement and institutional services
pros: BB&T has very good retirement plan benefits.  They are committed to employee product and process training.  There is also a great committment to client retention and the perfect client experience.
cons: BB&T puts too much pressure on the non sales personnel to meet very aggressive sales goals.  Also, the compensation if below industry averages, even in light of the company's stock price doing well.

headline: Good company and growing
pros: You learn a lot about insurance and different processes.  Very structured but due to the constant changes in the insurance industry some processes may be outdated.
cons: Stressful at times.  Not enough encouragement from some of the supervisors. Sometimes pushed to the max.

headline: Very Corporate
pros: The benefits aren't bad.  I get plenty of time off and the health insurance isn't too expensive.
cons: Raises are, for all intents and purposes, non-existent.  I'm by far the most productive employee in my department and, even though my boss would like to give me a real raise, he can't because of corporate mandated limits.  There's also miles of red tape.  So much so that nothing in IT ever gets done except for more committees and more red tape.  It's frustrating if you are the sort of employee who wants to really make a difference because that's not allowed.

headline: BB&T used to be a fantastic company to work for!!!!
pros: If you have a doctor's appointment, you are able to take deduct it out of your short-term instead of having to cut lunches, etc...
cons: Where do I begin? Alabama does not have many opportunities to grow within the company. It is all about who you know and how bad you suck up to them. This company prides themselves on being "empathic, reliable, responsive and competent." In reality, the associates are unable to provide these attributes to clients because BB&T has cut the branch staff to the bare minimum. The "upper management" within the state is so far removed from the branch, they do not understand the daily demands. It is CLEAR that BB&T thinks "everyone is replaceable" and in that is simply not the case. I have seen some AMAZING, high-producing co-workers leave. The mistreatment of employees is so rough, that clients are starting to notice. They are leaving in droves. It is also not just the "front-line" associates who are unhappy. After calling the back office many, many times, you make friends. You hear about their stories and the misery they are soaking in. Observation proves most people are either: 1) close to retirement and trying to stay positive or 2) actively seeking a new job. BB&T has proven time-after-time to be a selfish bank. When you walk into YOUR personal bank, do you see 3 or fewer people (during your 5-8 minute wait) and they consider it "fully-staffed?"

headline: Great people and atmosphere. Unattainable goals.
pros:
I really enjoy working in this company. Mainly because while they are a bank and the point of being a banker is sales, they really do try to focus on providing the clients with the best possible form of customer service.
401k, 2 weeks vacation, paid holidays
cons:
Not all clients will have an account to best fulfill their needs... leading to conflicts.
Branches are understaffed.

headline: Micromanaging at its best!!!
pros: Hourly pay was great for Lockbox Associate work
cons: Supervisor micromanaged however never seem to know what was going on. She loved to talk and take breaks all day however if anyone was talking you were reprimanded. Inconsistent supervision. Workers always made quote however it was never enough.. the supervisor and her assistant would eat..text all day however we could not have phones on the floor. Poor management on the weekend shift.

headline: Good not great

headline: BB&T

headline: Good Bank
pros: Time off for Holidays were great

headline: Great culture and values, dissappointed in staffing decisions

cons: very short-staffed and as a result the company overworks associates.  No overtime allowed.  Their pay does not supplement the amount of work they want you to perform (you're payed less for doing more than 1 role).  Repetitive conference calls/meetings.  Technology is not as advanced as competitive financial institutions

headline: Good values....changing culture....
pros: Work life balance is good most of the time.  People are friendly.
cons: Going through growing pains right now and senior leadership is struggling to align, which is making it difficult on the middle managers and rank and file to get work done.

headline: teller
pros: health benefits, 401K, vacation days, & holiday pay
cons: you have to be in your position 18 months before you can apply within the company.

headline: Not enjoying
pros: The Cons really outweigh the Pros but the company does have good people. Working here helped develop my skills as a professional but that is everywhere.
cons: Not really a company for millennials. Does not offer much flexibility. The company does not allow you to work from home when it makes sense much and there is not much opportunity for growth. BB&T is so far behind other banks on its systems also. It is 2014 and the bank's system are very outdated.

headline: Collections Rep I
pros: Very fast paced meaning time goes by very fast. Very good experience with customer service.
cons: They classroom train you for a week to learn basics. Nothing you learn in this week will be relevant to your job.  Then you hit the floor and expected to know what you are doing. Also, department policy states you must stay in the department for 18 months before you can take another job within the company.

headline: Business Development Officer
pros: Family oriented company. Big on people and community
cons: Going through a bit of identity crisis right now. Want to be a big bank but play by small bank rules...it doesn't work which clients recognize and it's stressful to employees

headline: Talk about backward place.... Commercial lenders go here to die...
pros:
- values based culture
- community involvement is excellent, proud of employees volunteering
- benefits are strong
cons:
- credit 100% runs the bank, and they're very arrogant thinking "they're better" than everyone else at managing risk
- problem with credit comes from the top - it's good ole southern white boys... if you don't belong to the fraternity, your opinion doesn't mean anything.
- regional leadership is quick to micro-manage, yet no one holds the credit officers accountable

headline: Not a good place to work.
pros: Winston Salem is a small town, so everything is close to headquarters.
cons: Management is spending money like its water.  There is a definite problem to be promoted past a mid manager level if you don't originate in the LDP.  Culture presentations via postings and quarterly video's was nice to hear, but I didn't see it lived up to.

headline: Love the company
pros: Family oriented, salary, benefits, career, incentives
cons: Direct management in some areas

headline: Great place to start
pros: They are a strong and stable bank. Well known in the market with a good reputation among business owners. They can typically beat competition on rates.
cons: The technology is from the 80's. Limited promotion, very much tied to being in the right place at the right time. It can be difficult to get credit officers to think outside the box unless they have seen it dozens of times.

headline: Under staffed!
pros: The benefits are pretty good!  There even better if you are signed up for the Peak Health program.  The vacation package would be better if you could buy days again.
cons: Management is non existent!  People (employees) walk all over you. There is no room for advancement.

headline: Great company to work for!
pros: The employees that I worked with were one of the great benefits of working at BB&T. Allowed for opportunities to grow and develop in your career path by providing some internal and external training. Benefits were great.
cons: Decisions should be made based on facts, not politics.

headline: Pros and Cons
pros: The ability to work independently at home was perfect.  The benefits were perfect.
cons:
My team leader and the other members of my team were located in Virginia and Maryland; I was the only evaluator in WV because I was the only candidate for the job who knew as much as I knew about the state.
The team leader and all other members are male.
My team leader thought he was helping me, but I suffered constant harassment and negative criticism from him.  The harder I worked, the more they expected.
Finally, the men were paid more than I was and were promoted while I was held back, receiving only a single 2% raise in 4 1/2 years.

headline: Work environment
pros: Great working hours. Pension plan. Health options where banks will pay full medical insurance.
cons: Not enough clients coming through branch, ton of phone calls to make.

headline: Strong company whose front line employees are haunted by uncertainty
pros:
The bank's training and development infrastructure is exceptional, I am consistently impressed by how much more competent BB&T front-line employees are than those that staff competing institutions.  The bank also pays reasonably well, and the sales incentives are attainable at the branch level.

The healthcare and retirement benefits are significantly better than those offered by competing institutions.

This bank is certainly making money and has an extremely loyal following among small businesses due to low employee turnover.  Since there is low turn-over, there is a sense of teamwork/camaraderie that is hard to create in banking.
cons:
While the sales incentives are pretty attainable, the sales pressure is significant, though you will get that in any banking role.  

My biggest pet peeve is the growing feeling that "something is up" with our branch model, and that information is being withheld from branch staff about upcoming changes.  It is difficult to be motivated when your personal trajectory is unclear.

We have had 0 communication from regional management regarding the changes to the branch and platform roles. Radio silence.

headline: It started out to be an amazing job
pros: Getting to know clients and building a relationship with them is one of my favorite things about this job, there is always something new to do, we do get paid vacation and sick days, however those days are hard to use because there is no staff.
cons: The shortage of staff members is getting be ridiculous, the goals they expect are almost unattainable because the employees doing more than required for their job title to compensate for no staff.

headline: Overworked
pros: Weekends off, other than occasional half day Saturday.  Good learning experience. Nice to see some clients on a regular basis.
cons: Always end up with overtime due to workload, but not allowed to get paid for it due to no overtime policy. You were made to back overtime out by taking longer lunches or coming in late or leaving early on another day they could work out during the week.  Also, had to make daily sales goals and make cold calls. List turned in each week, sometimes daily, of who you talked to and what product you sold or discussed. Sales affected pay raises which were practically non-existent.

headline: Not for a career just for experience
pros: Benefits, bonuses, comp time, overtime
cons: Hours, management, no integrity within company

headline: BB&T is a strong financial institution and ideally puts the client first
pros: great training for your position, ideally client focused. good brand name (for now).
cons: outrageously high sales goals (recently increased), short staffing makes day to day operations tough and providing the PCE nearly impossible. detached management. down training (IE managers have to be tellers and bankers, bankers have to be tellers, etc).
