headline: You want the truth?  Here's the truth for the Retail Banking Division.
pros:
BB&T takes pride in training.   I would say they have one of the BEST training programs in town.

Benefits/Compensation (Total Package) is on par with what you expect in the Washington DC Metropolitan area.
cons:
BB&T's Leadership is way out of touch with the current situation of retail banking. With the aid of technology (e.g., mobile banking), consumers do not have the need to come into the branches as much; however the goals remain extremely high - almost unachievable.  Tactics used to reach your individual goals is questionable at best.

The retail branch is run by Branch Bankers (formerly known as Relationship Bankers).  Your Market Leader (Branch Manager) is focused on loans and building the business pipeline.  However,  in most branches your Market Leader will say it's up to the Branch Banker to ensure they have Planed Purposeful Call (PPCs) on their calendar. So, in essence you have to build your individual pipeline as well as your Market Leader pipeline. 

BB&T provides wonderful sales tools (e.g., Hoovers), but in most cases it will not turn into sale opportunities.  They also provide you internal list, but nothing to promising comes from the leads.

Your best bet of survival at this bank is to go into an ideal branch where everyone works together (this includes Market Leaders), work at a busy branch, or adopt some questionable sales tactics. 

In sum, if you're seeking a Branch Banker position,  you have to have your sales game on par. They [BB&T] will tell you they are here for the consumer,  but really it what's in it for them.  If you are about building a meaningful relationship with your customer-THIS IS NOT THE PLACE FOR YOU!!

SPECIAL NOTE:  If you don't hit goals, be prepared for the boot.  This is the message that was delivered to employees a week ago by senior leadership:  "We got help them to the door as fast as possible"

Being a hard worker and nice DOES not pay off....SALES IS THE NAME OF THE GAME...NO EXCUSE.  Don't make numbers,  be prepared for a call night.

headline: Investment Services
pros: Great company culture. Mission is very strong, a lot of teamwork, and exceptional ethics. They strive to be the best for their clients, and have a great heritage and reputation. I'm in one if the newer markets and there is a lot of excitement for the upcoming opportunities to build profit and market share.
cons: Being an exempt employee, the pay structure can be challenging. It's hard to make it on the lowest pay grid for incentive, also a lot is taken out from the paycheck for taxes and medical. The communication between opportunities for advancement and employees needs to be communicated better. Feels limited mobility.

headline: Great Benefits, Poor Employee Advocacy
pros:
Benefits are wonderful, including insurance, payed time off, and sick leave.
Employees at all branches have a great working, family like relationship.
Great place to start a career in banking.
cons:
You get a great starting pay but if lucky can only expect an annual pay increase of 2%, if any.  
The bank operates on a skeleton crew which can cause many frustrations.
Very little chance for advancing in the company; nepotism at its finest.

headline: Constantly Changing Environment
pros: If you are motivated there is no shortfall of work present. Management strongly promotes those who can sell.
cons: Company became too focused on sales abd lost sight of the clients and the employees.

headline: Financial Advisors
pros: There is time flexibility when needed.
cons: Financial Advisor Company is an after thought to the banks. Advisors are competing with the banks for assets under management. High turnover. No company commitment to advisors.

headline: Financial Consultant
pros: A good place for an advisor that has limited scope or experience.
cons: A graveyard for serious advisors.

headline: Relationship Banker
pros: Benefits, Training, Paid Vacation (Fed Holidays), Great Hours, Networking
cons:
Limited growth opportunities
"Old Boys Club" Culture
Limited internal promotions

headline: Nice company, but challenged w resources
pros: The company has a good values-based culture, and works hard to stay true to it.  Service-focused, do-the-right-thing-for-the-client approach.
cons: Systems are so 1980's, and processes are too manual.  Senior management is required far too often for approvals of basic, low-level decisions.  It makes the company slow.

headline: It's a job
pros: Hours goal are reasonable management
cons: Salary is light for industry

headline: Beware...no security
pros: Pays well but stressful at end of month.
cons: Must be in a click...back stabbers

headline: Well compensated and very well treated
pros: Compensation is very generous when considering salary bonus plus stock bonus (requires 4 years vesting). Politics aren't very cut-throat, meaning that I haven't seen people being scapegoated or targeted. Pockets of vdry strong employees.
cons: Slow to change. Still stuck in the "well we just do it this way" mentality,  rather than embracing efficiencies.  Too much hierarchy.

headline: BSSO
pros: Great benefits and learning opportunities
cons: Lower salary than industry

headline: Dead end jobs for Relationship Bankers in Maryland
pros: great people to work with
cons: Unless you work in North Carolina or a city with operational offices, then there is very little chance to change jobs.  sales goals are unrealistic

headline: Great Company, Strong Values, Stellar Training and Growth Potention...IF you drink the Kool-Aid
author_position: Business Loan Administration Credit Analyst I
pros: BB&T offers top-notch training for employees. Pay for mid-to-high-level positions is somewhat competitive, though not enough to compensate for sub-par job location in many instances. Opportunities for growth abound, both within departments and inter-departmentally. Annual reviews are thorough (sometimes to a fault). Promotions are, for the most part, based on skills and performance. Training and experience gained at BB&T are easily transferable to other financial institutions.
cons: Corporate headquarters are in Winston-Salem, so the company loses many qualified high performers due to desired relocation. There is obvious and pervasive promotional preference given to graduates of the highly-valued (internally, at least) Leadership Development Program. The Company constantly creates new positions based on particular projects, which are often ambiguous and poorly defined. Freedom of thought is stifled, and team members who question processes or management are often stifled in their career growth (rather than commended for thinking outside the "BB&T Box"). Employees with a proven track record are often able to find comparable or higher-level positions with other financial institutions, often for significantly higher pay (pro for individuals, con for BB&T).

headline: Great benefit, lower salary compared to peer institutions.
pros: Flexible management, great benefits, dedication to employees, employee wellbeing is a big thing
cons: salary seems to be lower than market average for similar roles and/or institutions. i have heard many peers in other LOBs say similar.

headline: Awesome company !!
pros: Great management that is very knowledgeable, professional,  and fair. It feels like a small company in that you feel a teammate atmosphere.
cons: Benefits are fair. Not a lot of room for advancement unless you have a masters degree.

headline: Nice place to work
pros: CEO was very friendly and made a point to visit the different branches in the area and personally introduce himself. I felt that allowed me to feel like an important part of the company as a whole.
cons: Local "upper management" at main branch not very reliable (would not follow up/ through with concerns brought to her attention) at the time; however I believe that person is no longer with the company.

headline: Stressful, management plays favorites
pros: Good benefits, great coworkers, Bank Holidays
cons: Short staffed makes it hard to do your job and reach goals. No loyalty

headline: It's good company and great place to learn.
pros: Strong culture and provides an environment for success
cons: The company lacks innovation and open environment to take risk.

headline: Company has  a good culture.
pros: Very good training, good culture, values-driven company. People are extremely friendly and very supportive of each other.
cons: Very conservative ways to do business, traditional values. I work in Texas and its hard to line up the traditional ways to Texas way of doing business.

headline: My experience at BB&T can be explained as a rollercoaster ride.
pros: This job has great benefits and they match your 401k plan. You're not made to sell products however you must call people a couple times a day. Plus, I only worked every 3rd Saturday.  It was required that you work every Saturday. It's a great entry level job for someone who has normal retail experience. Paid holidays as well.
cons: Had very catty women working there making the environment unbearable. My manager didn't push his team a lot.He spent more time in his office watching sports on his phone instead of going out and getting clientele for the branch. They also have many unnecessary rules and it's easy to get in trouble over small things as a teller.

headline: Regional Employment Manager
pros: I really loved the fact that BB&T gives so much back to the communities that they serve.  The benefits are excellent including health, vision, dental insurance. I also enjoyed the communication opportunity for upper management, BB&T is very employee oriented.  There are also excellent time off policies including 10 Federal Holidays per year.  Of course, personal growth is ultimately up to the individual, but BB&T encourages the growth of their employees through training provided by BB&T University.  The work-life balance was sometimes hard to manage as a mother.
cons: The reductions in force in the last couple of years that involved many 20+ year employees losing their job.

headline: Benefits are great, chance for advancement-slim, company is downsizing
pros: Benefits are great!  Hope they continue for current and future employees.
cons: Business is so busy, growth may not be given in case the employee diligently seeks.  It is a job and one must not take it for grant it.

headline: Market Leader II
pros: Good benefits, pension, 401 (K), overall mission and vision minded to be the best of the best in banking.
cons: Work-life balance is very difficult if you are a clustered manager.  Upper management is spread very thin and could not possibly understand the difficulties of branch management with their large number of direct reports and responsibilities.

headline: Gained a lot of experience
pros: The pay was good and the experience
cons: Being a float teller the hours aren't guar

headline: New management in Processing/Underwriting with no knowledge of Mortgage experience and implements unnecessary processes that doesn't pertain to the job.
pros: Only working 8 hours and good benefits.
cons: No overtime, horrible salary, horrible management, inexperience associates.

headline: BRANCH BANKER III
pros: Overall, Great company to work for. You can really climb the success ladder quickly.
cons: The pay isn't that great.

headline: Good, strong, ethical bank with an almost family-like work environment. Many employees socialize afterhours & weekends.
pros: Great benefits and time-off policies. A bank that wants to do the right thing even if it takes a hit the bottom line for it.
cons: Low base salary and "capped" bonuses. Large breakdown in communication between upper and middle management.

headline: As long as you have great management you will be fine.
pros: Great Insurance, the benefits are awesome. Pay is decent, recent cutback have resulted in low to non existant bonuses for tellers.Part time has same benefits as full time.
cons:
Management sometimes demand to much from teller line. 
Hard to transfer, or move up

headline: Good place to work
pros: Fellow employees attitudes in the area I work with pitch in to get the job done.
cons: The inability for some to adapt to the constant changes mostly due to having to meet changing Government regulations.

headline: Extreme penny pinchers, with a lack of long term planning.
pros: Great group of employees within operations group.
cons: A lot of red tape, office politics and limited room for growth.

headline: Great place!
pros: Great training, awesome career advancement opportunities, benefits are one of a kind!
cons: Policies changes more often than expected,

headline: Very pleasant.  Adored my job until recently.
pros: The pros to working for BB&T are that if you are at least 30 hours, you do get some benefits that FT do.  The paid vacation, holidays, sick leave, 401k, health insurance is great.  Most of the people that they hire have proven to be ethical.  It is a very sound and solid company surviving The Great Depression and was one of the first banks to repay the bailout because we didn't need to be bailed out.
cons: A few cons to be noted is the fierce cut back on hiring and the amount of pressure and responsibilities Corp higher ups are placing on the branch staff. SELL!!SELL!!SELL!! And with all the federal regulations, the BB&T I was hired to work for no longer has the Community Bank feel with the benefits of a BIG Bank. You can't miss a day anymore without worrying that you are going to lose your job because we are so short staffed.  I don't see how they can cut anymore and they really should be recognizing how people are dropping like flies due to these issues. No work life balance at all!!   Former associates that have left for smaller banks or other professions are happier than they have been in a long time.

headline: Different, interesting, challenging
pros: Management expected you to perform at levels you were hired and encouraged you to do so.
cons: Senior management did not always consult with lower management on procedures

headline: Decent pay, but lack of help from Executives
pros: They pay is pretty good for a bank teller. I don't receive benefits but from my other coworkers it seems OK and even better when you reach a managing level. Also, i think after 5 or 10 years or working there you get an added week of vacation with a maximum of 5 weeks paid vacation in a year. I have heard of their pension plans and my manager appreciates that when she retires.
cons: Recently they have been making huge changes and issued a hiring freeze since the beginning of summer. My branch, along with other branches, have been short handed. Customers have not been happy due to the longer wait lines and lack of staff that they are accustomed to. Now we are told to work with what we have and everyone has to do more but not get compensated for the extra responsibilities. They still want us to hit our sales goals and pinch every penny as in save every pen and paper. They charge a lot of fees to clients which they have stated is their strategy to improve numbers for their shareholders. Why is BB&T's fee to cash a check one of the highest if not the highest compared to other banks. Meanwhile the busy bees have to handle the upset clients and then the guys upstairs wonder why we don't hit our numbers. Everyone has been frustrated and many people I've heard had given their notice when all this madness started. Each branch needs to bring in more with less. Also, their software needs a complete update! It takes so long to process a transaction and we waste so much paper. We don't even have pinpads to swipe a card. Also, I have not seen a large national bank who needed their customers to write a check in order to withdraw cash. I found that very backwards and outdated. And install the no envelope deposit ATMs at every location. You are losing a lot of money due to fraud at the ATMs. Not to mention you are just behind in times. Wells Fargo had those ATMs since 2008 or so.

headline: No advancement due to politics
pros: You have a job - this in not a career oriented Company
cons: You are told you can take training but have the company pay for it first.  I believed I would be reimbursed after I obtained a certification and that did not happen.  Women appear to be under valued.

headline: The worse experience of my professional career.
pros: ON THE SURFACE- life force, 401k, pension plan.
cons: This particular branch was the worse experience of my life. There was SO much going on I would be ASHAMED for KELLY KING to know! Politics, people backstabbing one another, management covering for their pets! Disgusting!!!!! Upper management "grooming their pets" to be whatever they want them to be. Never had a more disappointing experience IN MY LIFE!  Disgusting how HUMAN beings are taken out of the equation all together.... Nothing but market leaders trying to make themselves look good, whoring after whatever sale opportunity they can, whoring themselves and their employees!!! Despicable! I could see right through what was going on at this company. Listen, DO NOT WASTE your time,  and I mean your emotional time at this company!!!! Very alarming, misleading, basically they will try and sell this amazing job offer to you and once you get there it is like the worse job ever.

headline: Wonderful place to work
pros: Great benefits. They care about their associates well being
cons: Slow to promote. Try not to micromanage

headline: Branch Banker III
pros: Great benefits 100% 401k Match, Medical, pension, the employees and management are supportive and take interest in their employees. Plenty of paid holidays and not to many weeks over 40 hours.
cons: Cost cutting measures have put a serious strain on staff. Sales goal expectations are unrealistic. Management often only looks at production numbers and doesn't consider the operational/service/management aspect that is integrated into most platform positions.

headline: I worked for BB&T for 10 years. Most recent job title - Banking Network Branch Manager
pros: Good benefits. Can't think of any others.
cons: Micro-managing, unrealistic sales goals and high pressure from management. I left BB&T after being offered a position at a small town community bank. I struggled with the decision even though working for BB&T was so stressful, it was affecting my health, my sleep and quality of life. I am not one to give up easily because I put my heart and soul into my job. The beginning of the end for me was when I received an email from my Regional Manager regarding a "call night" that I volunteered for my branch because we were behind on our credit card goals. When I sent in the results of those calls to my Regional Manager, I received an email back in capital letters with many exclamation marks stating the results were completely unacceptable.  He stated that if I and my team and make "x" amount of calls we should have made "X" amount of contacts that should have resulted in "X" amount of sales.  So now I have to control  who answers the phone at night or is even home!  Unbelievable! He said nothing about appreciating our efforts and that we were doing all we could (and then some) to try to reach our goals.  This is the type of unappreciative management that BB&T has. In my area, employees are leaving in droves because of the direction BB&T is going with the bank.  What happened to this bank? What happened to Kelly King?  Over the years, one of the things that I heard over and over when something unethical would happen is "that is not the BB&T way".  Well, the BB&T way now is this - employees are just a number, they don't care about their employees at all and they don't care about their customers either.  Because if any of you reading this are customers of BB&T, the only thing they want from you is a "sale".  And if the employee waiting on you doesn't produce one, they will be looking for another job.  Leaving BBT was the best decision I ever made.

headline: The experience at BB&T has been a nice company to work for and has opportunities for advancement if you apply yourself.
pros: I enjoy the holidays and benefits that come with the job. The hours are always a plus for me since I came from working in retail. The people I work with are supportive and helpful.
cons: The staffing is an issue from time to time. They don't always follow through with certain things that they say they will assist you with. The changes occurring in the company are so frequent that you have to constantly adjust.

headline: Changing Company
pros: Very employee oriented. Great benefits
cons: Changing environment in leadership. It appears that compliance and account run the bank, but I am sure this is part of the banking environment we are in.

headline: Market Leader III, AVP
author_position: Market Leader III, Assistant Vice President
pros: Culture, Salary, Benefits, Managers are friendly and helpful
cons: None that I can think of

headline: If you're under the right management, its a great place to work with great opportunities.
pros: BB&T is a solid company/bank that isnt going anywhere anytime soon. The benefits are GREAT! Salary is okay. Higher then most banks.
cons: Depending on what branch you are in, dont think about having a life of the weekends. They will make you work every Saturday even when it is suppose to be 'rotated'.

headline: Relationship Teller
pros: You get a nice amount of vacation time. I'm also off every Saturday.
cons: They do not care about the employees.  They have cut his tremendously. From day to day you really never know what location you're going to work at. Your checks are up and down you may get 40 plus one week and the next week you may only get 28 hours. Very thankful to have a job, but when another job come through I'll be leaving with no hesitation.

headline: Teller
pros: Good benefits, closed holidays, some co workers
cons: Pay, hours, open Saturdays, having to get referrals

headline: Too many politics
pros: Better than average benefits. Solid overall company that is not going bankrupt any time soon.
cons: Difficult to move to other departments. Too many games played, once it's determined that you're not happy in your current department. The fraternity boy types are rewarded with managerial jobs, because they all golf and hang out together, or they've found their way into a manager's heart higher up the food chain. If you tell the truth, and it is determined that management is culpable, it will be ignored or you will be ostracized. Great place to be a manager, as long as you're good at the social game, brown-nosing, and politicking (as long as you're aligned with the people that win that game, otherwise you'll eventually be shown the door or be pigeon-holed into a dead-end career). Technology is a bit limited, and they've taken all of their training dollars away, except for "important" resources like developers making their highest visibility tool.

headline: Great Company and Values
pros: BB&T has exceptional benefits, treats their employees well and genuinely cares about giving back to the community.
cons: You typically do a job for 2-ish years before you are appropriately compensated for it.

headline: Coasting along
pros: Benefits    The so called Perfect Client Experience philosophy...it just needs to be consistently enforced.
cons:
Good ol'e boy system           Not what you know but who you know that gets you promoted
Management still running the bank like a small town bank rather than a progressive regional bank

headline: Good & not so good
pros: The benefits such as medical & eye insurance are great. So are the vacation time & holidays.
cons: The micro-managing & recent employee cuts are nerve-racking. Employee morale is low & client satisfaction seems to be declining. I've been with BB&T for a very long time & have never felt as insecure as I do now. I've seen managers come & go. Wish the one we have now would go.

headline: Great Company, Bad Management
pros: Wonderful benefits, Great Peak health program that helps pay for insurance. Training programs
cons: Working on Saturdays, Management is less than Good. No two branches are the same. Its not easy to advance if you are a woman, Cutbacks and hiring freezes are constantly hurting the teller line which hurts the clients. I work at a very small branch that is used to the same people, but since i have been here we are on our 3rd RB (now BB) lost multiple bodies here that are not replaced. Many branches have been severely hurt by the latest "cut backs". We do not feel important as a team. We used to have Teller appreciation week every year but that has stopped and we are not even recognized anymore. If we are the "FACE" of BB$T then we should be shown that we are cared about. We feel undervalued and overlooked. Morale is down to almost 0%!!

headline: Horrible Experience
pros: The company is a growing company
cons: The philosophy is a lie

headline: no room for growth
pros: The training at BB&T is great
cons: can not advance due to upper management

headline: job insecurity
pros: nothing really. only positive thing for me is that it's close to home.
cons: Summer 2013 they cut a bunch of managers and clustered them to be over 2 or more branches. Summer 2014 they did an additional cut and now managers are clustered to maybe 4 branches minimum. They cut the hours of a bunch of tellers from full to part time to further save on expenses which puts extra workload on the 1 full time employee at the branch with no pay increase. Very unrewarding and stressful and the part timers now have a financial burden with the pay cut. They think it's acceptable for clients to have extended wait times with only 2 employees at the branch which is a security risk.

headline: Happy I got out when I did.....
pros: Work/life balance, benefits (401k, insurance, PENSION), decent dedication to training/continuing education
cons: The organization is crawling with B-/C+ grade level employees with little experience to fulfill current roles, advancement at BB&T is dependent on 1) interpersonal and sometimes inappropriate relationships and 2) the amount of time you've input, intelligence and work ethic are severely undervalued,   middle and senior level management waiver on making clear and concise decisions which makes execution of tasks tedious and impossible,  market leaders/regional presidents lack the skill set,  professionalism, and influence to advance the banks loan portfolio to a higher quality,  executive management has become blinded by the "we haven't lost money x amount of quarters" speech -- they've lost focus on the basic bread and butter items that made the bank TRULY profitable (if you've read How the Mighty Fall, you might be shaking your head in a "this is true", fashion,   work load is often uneven, formal mentoring programs lack structure and purpose,  RIF's are the new NORM, being a number instead of a person is the new NORM.

headline: This is a great company to work for.
pros: BB&T gives employees excellent training and the company provides great benefits There is always someone to contact to assist employees and customers when needed. I enjoyed my time with the company and would love an opportunity to return.
cons: The company is based on the east coast and opted not to maintain offices in Nevada.

headline: Rollercoaster ride
pros: Great benefits, attainable goals, work/life balance
cons: Short staffed constantly, productive employees are not recognized for meeting or exceeding goals. Software is outdated and slow. Too much upper management, who are never seen visiting the branches to observe what cutting jobs is doing to the moral of the employees and trust of the customers,

headline: Little opportunity for Growth
pros: If you are in their community banking division their is little sales pressure compared to competitors.  They offer excellent health insurance
cons: If you are looking to grow your career and develop new skills BB&T is not the place for you.  Compensation packages are on very low end compared with competitors.

headline: Good place to work
pros: Great people to work with.
cons: Communication was lacking at times.

headline: A pretty surface with some messed up management...
pros: Benefits, PTO, pension plan, great health club called Life Force that encourages a healthy lifestyle for discounts on the health insurance. Employee camaraderie! Lots of teamwork.
cons: Short staffed, management can be tough on people. They don't like it when you try and get the truth. The market leaders tend to snitch on other employees and if you do something to upset one manager, you can get blacklisted.

headline: My co-workers were like family.
pros: My hours were pretty set, and my supervisor was awesome at scheduling. I really enjoyed the clients as well.
cons: Huge emphasis on selling products, and large turnover.

headline: Total disregard of customer needs
pros: prestige of working in finance, wear tie to work, decent benefits, single girls
cons: total attention to dollars of commissions produced. sell high commission annuities even though junk

headline: Good place to work
pros: Schedule was flexible and manager was family friendly
cons: I was a contractor so lack of benefits was the only con.

headline: Great place to work!
pros: Solid career advancement, promotions are done mostly internally, very mutually supportive atmosphere, low employee turnover, and fantastic training programs.
cons: Typically lower salaries than other competitive banks.

headline: RIF's are getting to be the NORM
pros:
Full benefits for PT employees.
Holidays, vacation, and birthday's off
cons:
Lots of micro-managing--conference calls, meetings, call nights, reports to complete when management can pull the results themselves.
Stressful work environment--the impression of never doing enough.
Sales goals that are unattainable.

headline: Don't think this is a small, community bank anymore!
pros: time off, employees you work with.
cons: Not good management training, conference calls on Mondays and Fridays where you get yelled out for not making your numbers. Events, working more than 1 saturday a month, no comp time for saturday. short staffed, when they loose someone, they don't replace them. Management makes you think that you have it good but you really don't. Treat their manager's like crap! The whole culture has changed with John Allison retiring. Employees are miserable, management gets blamed for everything. You are always pulled in 100 different directions. Sales, sales, sales even if the client doesn't need it!

headline: BB&T
pros: Birthday is a holiday that you get off every year
cons: Staffing, this bank operates with only two people in the branch generally

headline: At least they have a pension plan
pros: Clients are amazing.  Having holidays off is nice.  Birthday off is nice.  What would be awesome would being able to go on vacation when you have it scheduled.  What good is it to have 4 weeks of vacation if you can't use it:(
cons:
Salary 👎
Hours👎
Resources👎
Empathy👎
Motivation from management default response "be thankful you even have a job" 👎

headline: My experience with BB&T was both good and bad and very challenging..
pros: BB&T places high emphasis on continuing education and always has opportunities for growth.  The company has excellent benefits.
cons: For those in branch management  positions, the job requires an inordinate amount of time.

headline: Started off good but went down hill
pros: Great people to work with and for, not major sales pressure, great benefits, good work/life balance, good perks, federal holidays and accumulated vacations days off, decent pay in comparison to other banks.
cons: Been here for a year and have seen a major change in company culture, especially in the past six months. Changes at both branch and corporate levels, making it a bit more stressful, to a point of worry about job security. Past six months have lead to a few layoffs, short staffing which leads to longer wait times and more frustrated clients and no end on sight especially with hiring freeze. Other than that, usual cons especially being part time like having to float to other branches, a few monotonous moments, software and hardware seems a bit dated, but this comes with the territory and job title, if you couldn't handle those simple problems, I'm not sure you could do the job.

headline: Cutbacks are going to kill them in the end
pros: This is a great company to work for. They have wonderful benefits. Getting my birthday off each year is great.
cons: This is a "good boy society". If you do not fit into that mold it is difficult to find yourself advancing. The new branch positioning is not going to be a good move for their clients or the personnel that is left in the branches.

headline: Goals to High or unattainable for smaller markets
pros: They were good when they first took over our Colonial Bank, Lots of support and training.
cons: After 2 years they became the wicked "stepmother" Getting rid of all the older people that had 15+ years to avoid paying the higher salaries. Not good to employees, Always asked to do more with less, They change titles too much. After hours call nights to get accounts.

headline: Relationship
pros: benefits, salary, personal growth, leadership, opportunity.
cons: short staff, constant shifting, everyone needs to be cross trained, Saturday hours, branch info is horrible.

headline: Great Place to work!
pros:
The team of people whom I worked with were wonderful!
Get lots of long weekends due to bank holidays.
You learn a lot about banking
cons: lunch hours are never consistent

headline: I think BB&T is not sure of the road ahead.
pros: good benefits; still offering pension
cons: misguided management; need to define a direction

headline: BB&T teller interview
pros: good company with great benefits! and off for your birthday. There a lot of branches on the east coast, so you will be able to transfer to different areas. Also have a lot of different career oppurtunities
cons: Company has had a lot of cut backs lately. Employees that have been there 20+ years have been cut back to part time hours.

headline: Market Leader
pros: Good customer service culture, great benefits, great training.
cons: Below industry salary, no clear direction, rapidly changing sales culture

headline: Good company for starting a career in the financial industry.
pros: Great training program and great health benefits program. Still offers a pension plan.
cons: The company limits internal progression by basing movement ability on current job grade rather than basing on actual qualifications.  The company also has great values but not all areas of the company actually understand, live, and teach those values.  The company also faces struggles with technology and system development; consistently trying to develop applications and programs in house where it is obvious that is not a strength of the company.

headline: Teller
pros: Great place to work if you don't care about benefits and want to work less than 20 hours a week.
cons: Can't work more than 20 hours a week, yet management treats you as if you are full time and expects you keep up with the handouts and everything

headline: A good learning experience.
pros: Learn many aspects of retail banking and personal finance. You will learn how to advise clients to achieve financial success.
cons: Restructuring of the company has lead to an exodus of employees. Managers have become micromanagers and constantly threating about  future employment. The tides are rough.

headline: Working at BB&T
pros: Still offers pension. Still uses DOS to submit loan applications; system breaks down all the time.
cons: Closed minded, traditional values, overtime abuse;

headline: BB&T Once Was a Great Company to Work For
pros: Decent benefits and office hours are nice
cons: What has happened to this bank? Thank God I left July 2014! I became part of BB&T in a merger and was immediately pleased and loved the company I worked for. All associates and managers were nice and super supportive. The past year - year and a half... morale is TERRIBLE! This is probably due to enormous layoffs in 2013 and 2014. Unfortunately now if you are an employee or client of BB&T, you are only a number. No appreciation shown for consistently being a top performer. I don't know what went wrong other than maybe John Allison retiring. BB&T is banking BIG BUCKS- why jeopardize your reputation of "PCE" to your clients? I have never seen a bank with so little employees inside. Clients do not like it and frankly- it's NOT SAFE.

headline: I think if the employees changed their attitudes from negative to positive that would solve 95% of the issues
pros: you have the privilege of having your birthday off, 6% 401k match, you receive vacation within your first year of employment, longevity, team mates are flexible and helping, lots of training, classes, and quarterly test to keep you informed and up to par with your job description, there is an incentive in place called "peak health" where you can receive your medical health care benefits at a discounted price
cons:
the management tends to play favorites, the employees that have tenure and have been there for years all have problems and issues streaming from all of the disappointments they have had to endure over all the years they have been employed with the company.  They become BITTER instead of BETTER. That can be a problem for new hires because they come in over joyed to be employed by BB&T and after 3-6 months of dealing with bitter employees they are on other websites clicking on "careers", poor morale, they don't understand that HAPPY employees play a HUGE part in "THE PERFECT CLIENT EXPERIENCE" 
There is an employee merit program called 
Peak Health is hard to maintain and get the discount if you aren't already living a healthy life style 
Little to NO room for advancement 
Some members of management do not act professional or display their leadership skills well for example they talk about other employees among other team members. Which in part is the reason for the resentment and bitterness towards the company.

headline: Branch banker IV
pros: Pay is better than competitors,
cons: Under staff, 6 day week schedule,

headline: Great company and culture
pros:
Training opportunities are excellent if you'll use them
Mentors are available
Work/life is decent 
Total compensation
cons:
Salary could be more competitive
Technology resources are lacking
Not a cutting edge organization

headline: Good company, limited room for growth
pros: Decent balance of work/life and good benefits with the company.
cons: It's hard to move up in the center that I am in, women seem to be promoted more than men, who are more qualified for the position.

headline: Great Entry-Level
pros: Great co-workers, friendly work environment, work/life balance is great, good hours and good benefits. If you are giving your all, you will be recognized. Top notch training! They truly prepare you to fulfill your role and are very keen on additional training classes and seminars.
cons: Stressful sometimes working under specific sales goals, sales goals are sometimes unrealistic and hard to achieve. Lower level management will help you and encourage you, as long as you have a good manager. Every position is being stretched a little more thin, more responsibilities and less compensation. Like most companies doing more with less.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Excellent benefits and compensation, solid company to work for.
cons: Corporate is in Winston-Salem, hard to advance if unwilling to relocate.

headline: The company has been good to me in the time I worked there.
pros: BB&T is a good company to work for, there is opportunity to grow and make a career.
cons: The part that is not working for me is the schedule. It changes every week and I don't feel I have the freedom to work with my time.

headline: Good to start with and grow
pros: Great training, positive people, very supportive
cons: Regional managers have no understanding at branch level of what it takes to be Successful.

headline: quantitative and qualitative analysis , reporting to LOB
pros: work and life balance, 401k match,
cons: poor senior management,  slower salary rise, salary lower than market value

headline: BB&T to the Rescue
pros:
The way they came in and took over during the Colonial Bank disaster was awesome.
The employees that were living in that nightmare were thrilled the day BB&T took control and breathed a huge sigh of relief.
cons: My position was eliminated when the merger was complete, however the severance package was very generous.

headline: All smoke and no fire.
pros: Growing, corporate culture in North Carolina
cons: Executive leadership  and middle management (South Texas Region) does not listen to input from managers on the front lines

headline: Good Company
pros: The people are really genuine. The benefits are fantastic! The company truly has a strong culture that they operate by. Hard work is often recognized.
cons: Communication through the company can be lacking and disorganized. They tend to treat the people who work in corporate headquarters better than anyone else in the footprint.

headline: Good Stepping Stone
pros: Good experience as a first job out of college.  Learned a lot. Transitioning into a new roll will take some time, but you have to remember that success cannot be measured by what you did yesterday.  New positions will come along frequently, but you have to show that you have excelled at what you were hired to do.
cons: Low pay early on.  Management is constantly overseeing everything that you do on a daily basis.

headline: IT Security, Risk, and Governance
pros: If you are looking for a job that pays well with decent benefits, this may be the place for you.  Work-life balance is good and everything looks good on the surface.
cons: Don't expect to come in and grow your career unless you are a part of the good old boy network, brown nose, or can manipulate the higher ups.  If you are a good performer on your job, you'll be rewarded with being stuck in that position.  If you can talk the talk and claim you are always busy, you'll have a very bright future.

headline: My department was better than the overall corporation
pros: The people are awesome. Work-life balance was great (good vacation) and the company is very ethical and promotes family values. I had an awesome supervisor. He/She was "one of us" before getting promoted, so really understood the work.
cons:
In my specific role, there was not room for advancement. Once my boss got promoted, that's it -- they would have to leave before another opp for advancement came open. (We were a pretty specialized team.) So, it was out-to-go-up for me. I think Senior Management (outside of our building), and some of the product managers as well, had no idea what we did on a day-to-day, or how specialized/difficult it was. So, I think we were under-appreciated outside of our team. 

Also, even though we were a non-client-facing team, we had to dress the part ("because everyone else has to.")

headline: Great Benefits, difficult to advance.
pros: Amazing Benefits, had full paid maternity leave! Decent pay. Very good training.
cons: Poor Work- life balance. If you have to work a Saturday, then you're working 6 days that week since full timers aren't allowed any weekdays off. Not easy if you have a family. over time is a big no-no. Unless you have a manager really helping advance your career it's difficult to move up.

headline: Good place to work
pros: Pay is OK. Not the best in the industry but not the worst. You are also able to have a good work life balance. When projects are due you will be expected to work until your part is completed, but normally the pace is reasonable.
cons: Advancing in your career can be a challenge.  Some people stay in their same role forever.  You must make your own path as management doesn't seem to promote from within based on job performance alone. It can be done but networking is key.

headline: Room for growth but unrealistic sales goals.
pros: The company makes great contributions to retirement accounts.  Willing to promote motivated employees from within.  Offered a lot of training opportunities. Worked with a lot of great people.
cons: Sales goals were unrealistic for some markets and they micro-managed employees.  When employees did not perform to the standards set, the company did not provide support or assistance.  Spent 2-4 days a week on conference calls instead of helping clients.  Required unpaid hours outside of the normal business day making sales calls.  Salaried employees make a low salary considering the amount of hours they need to put in.

headline: A CULT
pros: Not much is asked of individuals.  Initiative is not rewarded nor expected.  If you work here and do not rock the boat you can work here for pretty much your entire career.
cons: Mediocre talent pool.  The best managers and bankers do not work here...they go someplace else and make more money.  BB&T does not pay market and as result the overall quality of its employees is pretty much the same across the entire platform...not very impressive. The employees who do work here love it, because they know as long as they stay in line, not much will be asked of them, and they wont get fired.  They also know they cannot get a job elsewhere doing the same job for equal or more money, because they  are not as sharp as their peers (otherwise they would have some gumption and not work here).

headline: It has been a good experience, but the culture leaves much to be desired.
pros: The people are the best things about the company. There's a strong work ethic and sense of accomplishment. The benefits could be better but for the most part are good. Work/Life balance is really good.
cons: The culture is far behind the times and much too conservative. The simple niceties are nonexistent (such as dress down Fridays, telecommuting, free WiFi). There's hardly any budget for training and education reimbursement only happens for certain employees.

headline: Terrible
pros: Only pros are the base salary and branch hours
cons:
-Micro Managers
-Sale pushers
-Worse customer service I have ever seen
-Managers don't care about you doing servicing all they care about is your numbers at the end of day
-Clients are just numbers to them
-Not enough staffing
-No lunches at times 
-No sense of urgency takes forever to get any answers from a manager
-You WILL be the managers assistant because they DO NOT feel like doing anything themselves other then going on "business calls"
-Want you to speak with 10 people per day doesn't matter if you called 40 people that day.4-
-Managers don't know how to do anything or manage their branches
-Don't care about customer complaints at all

I can go on and on

headline: Teller
pros: Great training and lots of room to move up and excel. Leadership was good however corporate was always pushing them pretty hard.
cons: Although growth in the company was often easily obtained, you would be required to complete hours upon hours of training. Almost unobtainable.

headline: it was informational.
pros: they offer very good benefits
cons: the position was too much pressure.

headline: Good place to work - has some irritants like most places
pros: Compensation is great, Company really believes and practices its values for employees and customers.  Opportunities for personal growth every year through training. Great life balance perks and benefits.
cons: As companies get larger the understanding of processes between departments gets clouded.  Sometimes and irritant.  As always too much work and not enough hours in a day.

headline: More concerned with image than internal communication and talent
pros:
Superior training
Solid benefits including pension and up to 6% 401k match
Wellness programs with reduce health insurance premiums
Well developed corporate values and vision
cons:
Silo'd product lines
Women tend to be overlooked for promotion opportunities
HR is more concerned with supporting management, not addressing serious employee concerns
Extremely conservative lending culture, difficult to support even long term clients.
Technology-challenged (internal systems)
Complex bonus structure restricts earning potential, salaries below national average
Many positions eliminated reducing efficacy to properly serve clients at local levels

headline: Awesome company with great values!
pros: This company has great leadership and benefits. I made many wonderful friends while working there. They like to promote from within but not many opportunities will come up.
cons: BB&T is losing its way a little right now. They are putting reducing costs (brought on by all the government regulations) above its employees.

headline: Great Company; Good values
pros: Excellent training; focus on customer service; dedicated to their vision, mission, and values
cons: None to add at this time

headline: Satisfactory
pros: Great work-life balance here at the bank
cons: many dedicated people, some waiting for their careers to expire

headline: on call teller
pros: they pay 20% premium as compensation in addition to the basic pay
cons: got a lot of last minute call

headline: Horrible
pros: Benefits were ok and started after 2 weeks
cons: Not enough staff to operate, lack of training, poor leadership and terrible management

headline: Wonderful Company
pros: Amazing training opportunities, benefits are top notch. Upper management the best I have had the privilege to work with/for.
cons: Though family is esteemed as important, a lot is expected from you. Makes it hard to balance work/family life.

headline: its alright
pros: growth in market, higher than average pay
cons: non-competitive products. Management is way to busy establishing the region to pay attention to individual growth

headline: Terrible experience
pros:
I am still trying to find,,,,finding.............did not find anything.. ............! 
Quit trying to find a pro !!
cons:
Mental stress
Incompetent management & leadership
To get things done you are at the mercy of everyone.
Impolite attitude
Give up nights and weekends
Practically it is not possible to do work even if you try to !
Will be promoted if you are ready to wipe $$$ !
Don't expect a pay hike for years
Bonus is a joke
High attrition -----TRUST ME THIS IS IN EVERY DEPT

endless...you will find one which I haven't for sure

headline: Great company and people
pros: Stable company, great coworkers, great benefits. Lots of career growth. Invests in employees.
cons: technology is dated. this is a cost saving measure, but it hinders customer service

headline: OK place to work
pros: The products that they provide to customers work well for being a conservative bank.  They have a very intuitive training program and they really want you to learn their company values and what they provide to their clients.  Benefits are pretty good also.
cons: Compensation is not up to par for what you are demanded of.  When they moved into South Florida, I don't think they did a good job of transitioning into that market.  They try to force client's to their values and if the client doesn't like it, it's like they didn't care.  Also there was really no support for their employees. Upper management is terrible when it comes down to getting support to the front line workers.

headline: BBT its all bad...I think your experience depends on which branch you get assigned to.
pros: Good Salary & Excellent benefits
cons: Weak/poor training.  Organizational culture varies drastically from branch to branch. The particular branch I worked at in my opinion was awful!

headline: The Best of the Best
pros: If you want to be in banking, you want to be in a bank that has a long history of sound judgement, good leadership and stability. That describes BB&T. The Corporate Culture is ethical, moral, client centric and tries hard to be entrepreneurial to the best of its ability with government regulations and oversight. It's the best place to be, if you want to be in banking.
cons: If you want to be in banking, be aware it's volatile, accountable to shareholders, under government scrutiny and regulations and these are hard times for the financial industry in general. The good banks get lumped in with the bad. BB&T will often over-compensate to protect profitability and brand. BB&T is a bit reactionary and will over-correct when profitability or stability or propriety is questioned. The over-correction creates insecurity in the ranks while the overall Corporate Culture remains strong. But I wonder how long.

headline: In theory, a great company; however too many managers get in the way.
pros: Good training, value of higher education
cons: lower pay for women, poor management

headline: I liked working with BB&T, but the lack of staff made it impossible to plan around your personal schedule.
pros: Good pay, paid vac. holidays and sick time. Provides benefits.
cons: System very old school. Some of the bankers extremely rude. rude staff to our clients.

headline: Busy, fast paced, well-trained position.
pros: Hours are flexible, training is superb.
cons: Pay is very low and customers tend to get flustered by BB&T's fees.

headline: If you are fortunate enough to get hired here, don't ever leave.
pros: BB&T knows how to take care of their employees. This bank pays better than any other and you get an incredible work/life balance. Many banks are notorious for giving tellers pitiful pay and then breathing down their necks for referrals-not here. They provide you with the proper training and compensate you beyond fairly. I've truly adopted another family working here.
cons: Although this is more-so a con for clients rather than employees, the company is a little "behind the times". Slowly but surely they are rolling out new technology (envelope free ATM's, improvements to the mobile app) which will help the company keep up with the "big banks".

headline: Great Employees
pros: Great training, good banking experience, great atmosphere
cons: Work to hard for minimum pay, short staff, no overtime.  Too demanding on sales, not good commission.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Excellent experience, opportunity for growth.
cons: Salary is not at industry level

headline: Great
pros: Good training and career progression opportunities.
cons: Some branches understaffed on Saturdays.

headline: A once great company and is imploding from within
pros: Great people but they are leaving as fast as they can
cons:
No room for advancement
Focus is not on job well done but numbers/ revenue only

headline: I'm over it
pros: You get brainwashed into thinking that your health benefits, 401k match, pension, and vacation overshadow the lack of common sense that desperately needs tending to.  If you work with a great branch, it can make the workload bearable.  I have worked with some very nice people, and I have had the opportunity to work in high volume branches.  The company had so much potential back in 2005 when I first started.  They made you think your actions were for the client, for the established relationship, and for everyone's well being.  Over the past years, they have bought out other banks to keep pace with the bigger banks.  It is producing a negative effect.  We use to have stock options, appreciation weeks, and an overall feeling of gratitude from management.
cons: BB&T is turning into the "bigger, badder bank."  Constant restructuring of employees, budget cuts, manic hiring sprees and then freezes, and pressure for high sales had made this place a dreadful place to work.  I use to love my job.  Now it's turning into a daily threat of job security, while the middle of the pack works to support management, and the workload is not returned.  They spend money on a worthless "video game" and then cut the budget so tight we can't even buy candy in the branch for the clients.  There is no room to advance except for branch management.  They hire IRM partners from external sources instead of training their own and then expect those same partners to have the values that get drilled into the existing staff day after day.  So the people that stay and want to move up in the company don't have anywhere to go.  It's all about what is new and shiny, and at the end of the day, it is a mens' club, or the good old boy network.  Period.

headline: Still growing
pros: Benefits are pretty good.  Current position allows for a great work/life balance.
cons: For as large as the company is, there is little room to grow due to the size of the department.

headline: Great place to work
pros: people and benefits are what separate this bank from the others
cons: usual cons working in a bank is the disgruntled customers so you cant avoid that anywhere you go.

headline: A good and profit driven bank.
pros: Great benefits; excellent pay.  Excellent training program.
cons: Culture has changed.  Much less focus on valuing people -- customers and employees.

headline: RUN!
pros: Benefits, Co-workers, Vacation time, birthday's off
cons: Management, personal growth, pay, always short staffed

headline: teller supervisor
pros: good pay, good benefits, pay is ok
cons: cant move up , doesn't give you a chance to prove yourself

headline: It provided mediocre income and decent benefits while waiting on something better to come along.
pros: The benefits are good and the income is decent for the area.
cons: Allows pseudo-nepotism and blatant favoritism to occur simply because certain relationships are outside the "textbook definition" of nepotism. (Whiteville-Call Center) Also, allows the aforementioned employees to stay on the clock for personal business that benefits themselves and management.

headline: Relationship banker II
pros: Being able to help people achieve economic success and financial security
cons: Can sometimes seem overwhelming with the work load

headline: Management needs a review
pros: Good benefits, there is the Life force program which helps encourage good habits and rewards. The Lighthouse project done once a year is biased however.
cons: The challenges outweigh the pros. Understaffed, technology is thoroughly outdated, very slow and rarely works properly. Training is minimal, and if a class does come up, management says no, they only let a select few go. Jobs are never posted, people are just placed in those positions. Upper management lets all of this happen. They condone it. Certain employees do what they want. Management allows it. It just depends on who you know.

headline: Values not shared by all management
pros:
Good benefits, specifically 401k and pension
Good corporate values.
cons:
Layers of middle-upper management don't buy into corporate value system. 
Micromanagement.

headline: Not many full time positions
pros: Paid holidays and vacation time awarded up front
cons: Not much room to obtain full time positions

headline: Graveyard for Investment Advisors
pros:
If you have little experience, low ambition, and no desire to be a comprehensive Financial Advisor or control the client process - this is the place for you.
Always openings as quality advisors usually leave.
cons:
High commission proprietary products are emphasized. 
Too many departments competing for the same client dollars.
Investment Counselors are reduced to being transactional based salespersons pushing BB&T in-house products.
High net worth clients must be passed on to Private Banking, Wealth Mgmt, Insurance, Trust etc. with IC's getting no compensation or incentive to do so.
High net worth clients have no clear idea of who is driving their planning process - these depts all indicate to client they are in charge. Any but the least educated client will withdraw from this confusing mess and seek a more cohesive advisor relationship elsewhere.

headline: Great benefits, lousy pay
pros:
They have fantastic benefits here!  401k match, pension, amazing healthcare options and a LOT of sick days.  

They like to promote from within.
cons: The pay is not comparable to other institutions for most departments.

headline: Rewarding hard work.
pros: Good pay. Good hours. Paid holidays off. Good benefits.
cons: Short staffing makes it difficult to make personal plans. A bit outdated systems.

headline: An old school company that is unwilling and unable to change.
pros:
The pay was decent and my co-workers created a good environment.
As with all things, it depends on your manager and their manager (that's the secret) make sure you interview with both and grill them.  If you're at the interview they want you... now just make sure you want them too!
cons: "But we've always done it this way" is a motto of many banks, but executive leadership that has been with the company their entire career make this a top down culture that doesn't understand or embrace change and technology.

headline: Ok Company
pros: Great benefits, positive company values and willingness to train employees.
cons: Not much potential for movement within the company.

headline: Great place to be and great benefits
pros: This is a company that is very profitable but has unfortunate suffered at the hands of government regulations.  Regardless, it is very well managed and continues to thrive in even a down economy.  The people are very nice, great work atmosphere, great opportunities to advance, pay is good, and the training is excellent.
cons: For those on the lower end of the corporate ladder, advancement is difficult.

headline: Overall good
pros: Good benefits, culture and work environment
cons: Management is very poor, workload is not distribute equally or in an efficient manner

headline: Great company to work for but has its ups and downs like most companies.
pros: BB&T provides excellent training and opportunities for growth.  They have very good benefits and opportunities for advancement.
cons: The sales mentality has increased to a point that I worry that it will override the values and culture of the company.

headline: Growing and enjoying it
pros:
Monthly coaching sessions, available middle management, ability to provide process improvement ideas. 
BB&T provides below average pay when looking at salary relative to the position that you have. However, the company compensates for this by readily offering leadership opportunities, training, promotions and challenging work opportunities if the employee is engaged. The company readily promotes talent from within. To me, this is far more valuable long term than an extra $10K a year. Besides the career potential, the leadership opportunities provide ways to grow and be challenged. In my 5 years at the bank, I've been promoted once and have had numerous leadership opportunities.  


Leadership training for managers makes it more likely that your manager/team leader will have a basic understanding of personality dynamics and basic level of empathy. Employees have agency and autonomy--the ability, skills and authority to make decisions about their work. In most situations, management and coworkers treat each other as adults and with respect. Taking sick time or going to a doctor appointment have never been an issue. Neither is asking for help when workloads are obscene (help might not be available, but there is no stigma around asking). The work week of 40-50 hrs creates good work/life balance. After 2 years, vacation days were 15+your birthday off + 10 bank holidays.The company is transparent in its values and policies. Generally, co-workers are nice and competent. Most people are engaged in their work and many are loyalty. The bank has never performed mass layoffs when the stock is under-performing. It has laid off chunks of employees if their jobs become obsolete and they don't have the skills to move into another role. All of this together creates an almost work-family like feel.

6% 401k match with really low Vanguard expense fund options. BB&T tiers employee's health insurance costs by health level and the health insurance is generous for coverage. 

HR department: competent from my limited experience.
cons:
There are major process inefficiencies, which many find frustrating. Way below market pay--pay for tenure vs. top performance. The company is really cheap when it comes to little things that make the work day pleasant and would show care, like providing coffee or water. 

The co-workers that are not competent (below average, always having a bit of trouble, not able to complete tasks on time and by others standards) are not fired. One would have to seriously underperform or be downright disruptive to be fired.

Over the past 2 years, the bank has attempted to flatten the management system, consolidating senior executive positions and regions. There is less room to grow in seniority later in one's career, making the proverbial corner office not likely to be attained.

headline: Wonderful Benefits
pros: Wonderful Benefits, very flexible. LOVE the people.
cons: Environment varies depending on the people

headline: Relationship Banker I
pros: Great company with AMAZING benefits for all!
cons: none to report at this time

headline: Slow Growth
pros: Office Culture, Building Perks, 40 days sick paid
cons: Personal Growth, Favortism, Not a challenging job

headline: Stuck in neutral
pros: Simple to get things done
cons: Do not have outside influence

headline: GOOD company !
pros: Benefits, opportuinty to move up if you wish too and you are good.
cons: if you work on the teller side they do not accomadate to the needs of tellers at all.

headline: Excellent Workplace!
pros: Great place to work for. Great pay and incentives for employees!
cons: Different standards for same policies

headline: Not a bad company to work for (collections department)
pros: The health benefits, 401k, and FSA are great. The pay is fair enough.
cons: The job in and of itself by nature (collections) is stressful. This is not helped by the fact that the company has made some major blunders in the last year and not handled transitions well.

headline: Overwhelming
pros: Culture and leadership structure are strong.
cons: Sales, sales, sales... never ending, relentless sales goals.

headline: Confused about what direction to focus on
pros: The benefits at BB&T are great.  6% 401K matching and up to 40 days off for sick time plus vacation.
cons: They are confused about what to focus on and have created multiple reports for everything.  No time to actually work.

headline: Good Company
pros: Strong culture and values.  Good work/life balance.  Team environment with ok compensation and good benefits.
cons: Lack of career progression for younger talent.  Career growth is driven by age not contribution to the organization.

headline: Ehhhh
pros: Job security and the benefits are ok
cons: Slow changing environment-difficult to bring up creative ideas

headline: No Room For Growth
pros: Teamwork, good environment, Great learning opportunities
cons: No Room for growth. I have been at the same position for over 10 years.

headline: Excellent in most categories.
pros:
Great medical benefits and health program.
Good 401(k) with excellent match
Pension plan is offered after a 5 year vest time frame.
cons:
Only 10 vacation days for the first 5 years unless officer and above 
Net pay reduced in comparison to other institutions because of other benefits offered 
18 month wait time frame before eligible for another position within the company.

headline: Best Bank in Town :-)
pros: Everything is wonderful working here !
cons: Nothing bad can be said

headline: It is a bank job--no better or worse than any other bank job
pros:
Good work/life balance
Nice compensation package
I feel secure working in a branch
Sr. Management all seem to be good, decent people
cons:
It is a Boy's Club, and there are definite cliques
Nepotism is a major problem in this market
The promotion structure has more to do with who you know, than how you perform
Banking partners (such as merchant, treasury, etc) are overloaded to the point that they cannot work the referrals branches are required to send, and this leads to great frustration for everyone
Staffing is skeletal, and branch staff frequently work overtime without showing it--senior management knows this and has spoken openly about it being appreciated

headline: Great Company!
pros: Benefits are wonderful, management is great, great place to work!
cons: Little room for advancement but it is there!

headline: Great place to work, very stable company with opportunities to move up and within the company if you choose to.
pros: Good training program, continual training depending  upon your position. Very good people within the company, they strongly believe in expecting you to give your very best and only hire people who show those qualities and possess the values required of BB&T.
cons: Could use more hands on training after the "school" type training ends prior to being put in the new position. Sometimes when the branches are understaffed it puts strain upon the existing employees.

headline: Great Company that takes care of you.
pros:
They pay for your health/dental/ vision insurance
Big company treats you like family.
Even the little guy can get a word in to the head honcho
If you're not satisfied with your current position there is room for growth.
cons:
Banking has changed and regulations have been more strict. Banking has definitely become more sales based because of the internet revolution.  
Corporate America need I say more?

headline: Micromanagement with great success
pros:
Great training and preparation for your functional role.
Transparent performance measurements.
Profitable company.
cons:
Your behavior is monitored daily, weekly, monthly, quarterly.
Emphasis on process over results.

headline: Credit Analyst
pros: Strong benefits, values driven company
cons: Very repetitive at times

headline: Easy job for low wages.
pros: Great place to work (in the branch) for working day to day.  Once you clock out you are done for the day.  It is a great way to interact with people throughout the day and not have to worry about work the next day.
cons: The only way to advance in the branch is to be a sales person.  Whether people need a product or not you are expected to sell.  The pay is terrible but the job doesn't have a lot of cumulative stress.

headline: Average at best
pros: Great people, decent benefits and bank holidays
cons: Management out of tune.

headline: Says that they value work/ family balance, however all is not as it seems. Management will misrepresent job demands.
pros: 4 days per year vacation. You get all the post it notepads that you want.  They even give you a computer and a stapler.
cons: Hiring manager says that they value work/ family life balance, and that this is a 40 hour per week job.  After hire, it was demanded that I work 70 hours per week if I value my job. I am a professional in my field with over 20 yrs experience at other banks, so I am familiar with job demands at competing institutions.

headline: Mortgage Loan Processor III
pros: The only plus is the 80 hours of sick leave you get a year. This can be used for your children, spouse, or yourself.
cons: Benefits are not good. Healthcare for a family of 5, I pay $495.00 per paycheck. Copays are $35.00, I am not sure why there are so many reviews saying the benefits are great. I left Bank of America to come here and my benefits were much better. I had 4 weeks vacation. Here I got 2 weeks. Healthcare was $305.00 per paycheck. Technology is outdated and management does not provide training and is not evolved at all. Good ole boys network. Branches might be different but corporate BB&T is AWFUL.

headline: BB&T is a highly profitable values driven organization
pros: The bank has a great culture and benefits package.  Upper management supports the vision and culture of the bank.  Great place to work.
cons: While the culture is certainly wonderful, it can be viewed as fairly conservative (which is not uncommon in the banking industry).

headline: In the begining it was wonderful
pros: A chance to move to other departments
cons: company is not family friendly

headline: I love the people I work with and our clients are the best.
pros: Training and updating are awesome. The banking rules and regulations change frequently, BB&T keeps its employees apprised and provides the training necessary.
cons: They like to keep part-time tellers exclusively. Only two tellers at each branch are full time in my area.

headline: BB&T has been a great experience over the last year
pros: BB&T has some great people, people with principles and ethics that do things that benefit the client and do things the right way. Very refreshing to see in the industry. Good benefits, decent pay.
cons: Systems and processes could be better, recent changes in Client Service Unit have not been handled well. Pay is average to below average

headline: Great corporate Culture
pros: Many Opportunities for young professionals.
cons: Mostly based in the Southeast. (Currently Expanding)

headline: Great Company To Work For
pros: They have excellent benefits and the people treat you extremely well. Everyone was extremely helpful and welcoming
cons: I didn't really have too much to complain about during my time with BB&T

headline: Stayed longer than anticipated
pros: Same vision, mission, values purpose.  Consistency.
cons: Constant restructuring which makes some employees concerned about their future with the organization. Causes uneasiness and concern.

headline: Same as any other big bank
pros: Culture outside of sales is great. Vision of executives is outstanding. Unfortunately it is not being executed well at the branch level.
cons: Branch and regional managers are nothing but product pushers. Un-insightful, un-imaginative, and care about sales goals more than their own people or customers. They claim to be different than similar banks, and they are...in the worst way. Do not work for BB&T if you really want to help people with their finances. That goes for any retail bank though.

headline: Charlotte HR/ Commercial Loan  Department
pros: Decent Benefits, Okay Schedule, Being Hired on as a Temp you paid as someone that has been there many years
cons: No Advancements , HR and Management will Discriminate and Promote Friends

headline: Good, but very time intensive
pros: Good experience, good contacts, very ethical
cons: Lots of work, very time intensive, if need to test then you lose weekends more frequently

headline: Nice place
pros: They have very good benefits.
cons: Very hard to advance your career.

headline: Very efficient, stable bank.
pros: Benefits were great, opportunities to advance abounded, and there were several reward/recognition programs in place for merit.
cons: It can always be difficult to work for such a large company. Sometimes you feel like a number. But even then, you get to know management from your region and establish working relationships with many people within yourr footprint.

headline: More Bad than Good
pros: Most people awesome to work with
cons:
Terrible Management
Good Ole' Boys Club
Archaic

headline: Work well with clients and associates.
pros: Excellent benefits and training, very diversified company, have all the right tools to get the job done.
cons: Little bit short staffed, working on hiring more employees to fill positions.

headline: Financial Center Leader
pros: No pros that I can recall.
cons:
1.  50-60 hour work weeks.  
2.  Pay is pathetic compared to the competition.  
3.  Very political organization and hard to move up within the ranks if your not smoozing with senior management.  
4.  Call nights several times a month (which do not guarantee any further sales results).  
5.  Sales, Sales, Sales, Sales driven - Senior Management is highly driven by your production figures.  
6.  Monthly sales meetings are the same bunch of bogus every month (area managers talk down to us like we're elementary children ..."remember to always open a checking account, blah blah blah).  
7.  Never had an opportunity to recruit and select my own staff from interviewing.
8.  Constant shortage of staff within branch - yet goals are still held to par (in 2012 I averaged 1 teller).
9.  Inconsistent underwriting among managers.
10.  Vacation times only permitted if appropriate coverage within branch.

....the list goes on...

headline: Vice President
pros: Great Place to work for .
cons: none whatsoever , great company to work for .

headline: Great People and culture
pros: Outstanding people throughout the organization.  Very talented and knowledgeable in the financial industry.
cons: Do not seem to look up enough to see what others are doing even if it is to just understand what is driving changes in the industry.  The budget and project process is very informal and relationship based.

headline: Great company
pros: Casual environment, good teamwork, great work/life balance.
cons: Small company so not that much room to move around.

headline: Great Company
pros: Family environment, benefits, not numbers oriented
cons: pay, hard to move up

headline: Ten    years with company
pros: Came onboard because core values mirrored my personal core values. Direct manager who valued my input and expertise and gave autonomy to make decisions.
cons: Core values have been lost in regional level management.  The bank has cut associates with longevity of ten, twenty and thirty plus years to bring in younger and less experiences associates. Staffing in branches is less than adequate where associates get no break for lunch unless manager steps in to work for them as a teller or customer service.  Operations support is non-existence and staff fears their dictatorship when they do show up.

headline: Friendly company with great corporate values
pros: Friendly people, supportive environment, and great training allowed me to acclimate quickly. I found that the company wanted me to succeed and allowed for me to make mistakes in the learning process without fear of retribution.
cons: Close minded, traditional values, little room for advancement.  The company started out small in the south and it is reflected in the corporate culture.  You are expected to be a reflection of their faith based values that are stated in the corporate beliefs.

headline: Still has some catching up to do technologically but is very very stable
pros: education driven, flexible, stability, family oriented
cons: Needs to improve on technology

headline: Great company to work for.  I have been in banking over 20 years and this is the best by far
pros: Wonderful senior mgmt.  They really do care about their employees and balance of work and personal life.  They promote from within and give each and every employee the tools and training to grow and develop.  Morale here is amazing.
cons: The only con that I can find is that perhaps more marketing in the Texas area.  We are fairly new here and many people do not know about us.

headline: Jealous Leadership that condemns excellent performance because of feeling treatened
pros: Health Insurance, Great work schedule, Vacation time
cons: Very Poor incentives for great job performance, Punished not praised for great performance, I make 12.22 an hour or 23462 per year and I have a College degree in a related field of study.

headline: Walk the walk don't just talk about values
pros: Depends on your manager. New Bank org chart came out beginning of January 2014 so maybe all employees will be included in same retirement benefits and opportunities.
cons: Not all employees get the pension.  Many do and they assume everyone else does. In my 10 employee team everyone else including my manager had better retirement benefits.
